c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach Jolles with captains Brody, Josh, Cameron, and Blake
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b: The men's lacrosse team is coming in hot with 20 new amazing players for the season in addition to our returning all-stars. Coach Jolles has high hopes for this team who's been training all summer to bring home another regional championship.

c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach Stephens with captains Riley, Paige, and Shayna
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b:
Coach Stephens and the women's lacrosse team have been practicing during the cold winter months in preparation for this year's spring season. We're all warmed up!

Come support the new offensive line and starting goalie this Saturday as we open against Blake High School.

c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach Taylor with captains Roger, Andy, William, and Devin
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b:
This year men's tennis is coming in hot with 24 players! Lead by seniors Rodger, Andy, William, and Devin, this team is feeling stronger than ever. 

The Eagles have their season starting soon and would love to see everyone out at a game!

c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach Rizz with captains Yasi, Marcy, and Christine
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b:
This year men's tennis is coming in hot with a bunch of new players! Lead by seniors Yasi, Marcy, and Christine, this team is feeling stronger than ever. 

The Eagles have their season starting soon and would love to see everyone out at a game!

c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach Madden with captains Andy, Jimmy, Cesar, and Edwin
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b: The men's soccer team is back this year stronger than ever! Lead by captains Andy, Jimmy, Cesar, and Edwin, the offense is looking stronger than ever. Come support our upcoming senior night!

c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach White with captains Erin, Anna, and Kelly
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b: The women's soccer team is back this year stronger than ever! Lead by captains Erin, Anna, and Kelly, the offense is looking stronger than ever. Come support our upcoming senior night!

c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach Brown with captains James, Elijah, Noah, and Oliver
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b: With a starting team of 30 exceptional players, the mens basketball team is back to redeem their shot at the playoffs this year. Coach Brown has been working hard all winter with the Eagles to train and prepare for the season ahead!

c_c21e4bcc456c44e9badde8007bd88975: Lead by Coach Harvey with captains Leanna, Kirsten, and Nicole
c_7302f31130f5404799ee45a5b449f33b: The women's basketball team has 23 amazing players this year! Starting out the season strong with our returning starting team, the Eagles are hungry for redemption from last year's playoffs. They hope to see you out at a game soon!

c_c96wqe6ivvke1td9hkl0rdb3j: 105p. Although a thing may not be bad [or wrong] in itself, yet, if it is of bad example, it is not to be done. 2 Inst. 564.
105o. It is better to suffer every wrong or ill, than to consent to it. 3 Inst. 23.
105n. A wrong is not presumed. Co. Litt. 232.
105m. It is better to recede than to proceed wrongly. 4 Inst. 176.
105l. The idea of rights naturally suggests the correlative one of wrongs; for every right is capable of being violated. Black's, 1235.
105k. The greatest enemies to peace are force and wrong. Co. Litt. 161.
105j. All things are presumed against a wrong-doer. Broom, Max. 843.
105i. A right does not (or cannot) rise out of a wrong. Broom, Max. 738, note; 4 Bing. 639.
105h. Whatever is against the rule of right is a wrong. 3 Bulst. 313.
105g. Wrong is wiped out by reconciliation. Bouv. 124.
105f. Wherever there is a wrong, there damage follows. 10 Coke, 116.
105e. The rigor or height of law is the height of wrong. Hob. 125.
105d. Law hates wrong. Wing. Max. p. 563, max. 146; Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, no. 62.
148b. 105c. He who does not repel a wrong when he can, occasions it. Jenk. Cent. 271.
105b. No one shall take advantage of his own wrong. A man will not be allowed to derive a benefit from his own wrongful act. Branch, Princ.; Jenk. Cent. 161; Co. Litt.
105a. One wrong does not justify another. Broom, Max. 395. A wrong does not excuse a wrong. 11 Exch. 822; Branch, Princ.
105. WRONG, WRONGFUL ACT (See also: MALICE -:- CORRUPT -:- ERROR)

104hh. If there be no inference which leads to a different result, words are to be understood according to their proper meaning, not in a grammatical, but in a popular and ordinary sense. 2 Kent, Comm. 555.
104gg. General words do not derogate from special. Jenk. Cent. 120. General words are to be understood generally, or in a general sense. 3 Inst. 76; Broom, Max. 647.
104ff. Words ought to be made subservient to the intent, not the intent to the words. 8 Coke, 94; 2 Bl. Comm. 379.
104ee. The meaning of words is two-fold,—mild and harsh; and words are always to be received in their milder sense. 4 Coke, 13. 4 Prolixity: being wordy; using more words than are necessary. (1 00)
104dd. Those words which are spoken to one end ought not to be perverted to another. 4 Coke, 14.
104cc. In regarding words, it is not the words, but the thing and the meaning that is to be inquired after. Jenk. Cent. 132.
104bb. Terms of an art should be explained from the art. 2 Kent, Comm. 556, note.
104aa. The force of a word is to be first examined, least by the fault of diction the sentence be destroyed or the law be without arguments. Co. Litt. 68.
104z. The sense of words is to be taken from the occasion of speaking them; and discourses are always to be interpreted according to the subject-matter. 4 Coke, 13b.
104y. There is no porlixity where there is nothing that can be omitted. Vaugh. 138.
104x. The full meaning of a word should be ascertained at the outset, in order that the sense may not be lost by defect of expression, and that the law be not without reason. Co. Litt. 68.
104w. From a few words or hints the understanding conceives many things. Litt. s. 550.
104v. From the words of the law there must be no departure. 5 Coke, 119; Wing. Max. 25.
104u. Words are to be received with effect, so that they may produce some effect. Bacon, Max. reg. 3; 2 Smith, Lead. Cas. 530.
104t. Equivocal words and those in a doubtful sense are to be taken in their best and most effective sense. 6 Coke, 20.
104s. The meaning of the words is the spirit of the law. 5 Coke, 2.
104r. Words should be taken most strongly against him who uses them. C.L.M.; Bacon, Max. 11, reg. 3; Noy, Max. 48.
104q. The meaning of a word may be ascertained by reference to the meaning of words associated with it. Broom, Max. 523; Corning v. McCullough, 1 N.Y. 47, 69.
104p. Words should be understood effectively. Rickets v. Livingston, 2 Johns. Cas. (N.Y.) 97, 101.
104o. General words must be restricted to the nature of the subject-matter or the aptitude of the person. Bacon, Max. reg. 10.
104n. The proprieties of words [proper meanings of words] are to be preserved or adhered to. Jenk. Cent. p. 136, case 78.

104m. Words ought to have some operation; they ought to be interpreted in such a way as to have some operation. 8 Coke, 94a. 3 Equipollent: equal in force, weight, validity, etc. Equivalent in meaning or result.
104l. Whenever the same words express two meanings, that is to be taken which is the better fitted for carrying out the proposed end. Dig. 50, 17, 67.

104k. Words are to be understood with reference to the subject-matter, that it may be preserved rather than destroyed. 6 Coke, 62; Bacon, Max. 17, in reg. 3; Plowd. 156; 2 Bl. Comm. 380; 2 Kent, Comm. 555.
104j. The spoken word flies; the written letter remains. Broom, Max. 666
104i. What is never sufficiently said is never said too much. Co. Litt. 375.
104h. Words are indicators of the mind or thought. C.L.M.
104g. He who confines himself to the letter goes but halfway. C.L.M.
104f. Words ought not to be accepted to import a false description, which may have effect by way of true limitation. Bacon, Max. reg. 13; Broom, Max. 573; 4 Exch. 604.
104e. Relative words refer to the nearest antecedent, unless it be prevented by the context. Jenk. Cent. 180; Noy, Max. 4; Wing. Max. 19; Broom, Max. 606.
104d. It matters not what becomes of equipollent expressions. 5 Coke, 122.
104c. Where words are not conjoined [used disjunctively], it is enough if one or the other be complied with. Dig. 50, 17, 110.
104b. It is the same thing to say nothing and not to say sufficiently. 2 Inst. 178.
104a. Coupling of words together shows that they are to be understood in the same sense. Bacon, Max. reg. 3; Broom, Max. 588.
104. WORDS & MEANINGS (See also: CONSTRUCTION -:- INTENT)
103v. The will of a testator is ambulatory until the latest moment of life (that is, he may change it at any time). Dig. 34, 4, 4; 4 Coke, 61; 2 Bl. Comm. 502.
103u. A madman has no will. Dig. 50, 17, 40; Broom, Max. 314.
103t. The right of testaments belongs to the ordinary. C.L.M.
103s. A right growing to a possessor accrues to the successor. Halk. Lat. Max. 76.
103r. Things written in a will which cannot be understood, are the same as if they had not been written at all. Dig. 50, 17, 73, 3.
103q. When two conflicting wills are found the last prevails; so it is when two conflicting clauses occur in the same will. Co. Litt. 112
103p. It concerns the state that men's last wills be held valid, [or allowed to stand and have their effect.] Co. Litt. 236b; Black's, 1010
103o. A testament is the legal declaration of a man's intentions which he wills to be performed after his death. 2 Bl. Comm. 499.
103n. The right of survivorship is preferred to encumbrances or to a last will. Co. Litt. 185.
103m. No one is presumed to trifle at the point of death. CycL Dict. 689
103l. No man is presumed to be forgetful of his eternal welfare, and particularly at the point of death. 6 Coke, 76.

103k. A person dies intestate who either has made no testament at all or has made one not legally valid; or if the testament he has made be revoked, or made useless; or if no one becomes heir under it. Inst. 3, 1, pr.; Dig. 38, 16, 1; Dig. 50, 16, 64.
103j. A testament is the witnessing of one's intention, made under no present fear of danger, but in expectancy of death. C.L.M.
103i. Old age does not alone and of itself vitiate a will or a gift. Jackson v. VanDusen, 5 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 148, 158.
103h. Every will is completed by death. A will speaks from the time of death only. 3 Coke, 29; Co. Litt. 232; 4 Inst. 279.
103g. In testaments, the will of the testator should be liberally construed. Dig. 50, 17, 12; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 507.
103f. Give the things which are yours whilst they are yours; after death they are not yours. 3 Bulst. 18.

103e. In wills the intention of the testators is more especially regarded. 3 Bulst. 103; Broom, Max. 555; Jenk. Cent. 277; Co. Litt. 322. Intention gives effect to the wording of a will. Dig. 30, 1, 12, 3.
103d. Wills ought to have the broadest interpretation. Jenk. Cent. 81.

103c. Where an ambiguous, or even an erroneous, expression occurs in a will, it should be construed liberally, and in accordance with the testator's probable meaning. Broom, Max. 437, 568; Dig. 34, 5, 24.
103b. Where two things repugnant to each other are found in a will, the last shall stand. Co. Litt. 112b; Shep. Touch. 451; Broom, Max. 583.
103a. The last will of a testator is to be thoroughly fulfilled according to his real intention. Co. Litt. 322.
103. WILLS, TESTAMENT (See also: INHERITANCE -:- DOWER)
102l. The People have given to their Governors no Power to do an unjust thing, such as to make an unjust War, for they never had such a Power themselves. Locke, Treat. 2, 16, 179.
102k. It is best and most prudent to have commercial intercourse with all nations, but political ties with none. American Maxim.

102j. An aggressor, who puts himself into the state of War with another, and unjustly invades another's Right, can never, by such unjust War, come to have a right over the Conquered. Locke, Treat. 2, 16, 176.
102i. International law is affected by positive (written) law, founded on usage, consent, and agreement. 1 Kent, Comm. 2.
102h. International law originates in the law of nature and is based upon certain Divine decrees which have separated nations and men.
102g. Fraud and deceit do not exist in international affairs or in a state of war as no remedy of law exists. C.L.M.
102f. Enemies are those whom we declare war upon, or who declare it against us; all others are traitors or pirates. 7 Coke, 24.
102e. International law or the law of nations is that law which regulates the intercourse of nations. 1 Kent, Comm. 1, 4.

102d. One may destroy a man who makes war upon him, as he may kill a wolf or a lion, because such men are not under the ties of the Common-Law of Reason, and have no other rule, but that of force and violence. Locke, Treat. 2, 3, 16.
102c. The vanquished is to be condemned in costs to the victor. —A Maxim of the Law of Nations.
102b. Peace is to be secured by victory, not by negotiation. Cicero's Writings.
102a. Conditions are made by conquerors, to be observed by the conquered. —A Maxim of the Law of Nations
102. WAR, LAW OF NATIONS
101m. Truth is the mother of justice. Halk. Max. 185.
101l. Truth which is not sufficiently defended is overpowered; and he who does not disapprove, approves. 3 Inst. 27.
101k. Truth is lost by excessive altercation. Hob. 344.
101j. Truth in the name takes away error in the description. Tray. Leg. Max. 614.
101i. Fact in pleading is circumstance, act, event, or incident, while truth is legal principle which declares or governs facts in their operation and effect. Gerrity v. Brady, 44 III. App. 203.
101h. We can do nothing against truth. Bouv. 141.
101g. Truth fears nothing but concealment. 9 Coke, 20b.
101f. Truth, by whomsoever pronounced, is from God. 4 Inst. 153.
101e. Suppression of the truth is equivalent to the expression (or suggestion) of what is false. Addington v. Allen, 11 Wend. (N.Y.) 374, 417. Paul v. Haddley, 23 Barb. (N.Y.) 521, 525.
101d. Facts are more powerful than words. Bouv. 126.
101c. The law never suffers anything contrary to truth. 2 Inst. 252.
101b. He who does not freely speak the truth is a betrayer of the truth. Black's, 2d. 979; 4 Inst. Epil.; Bout,. 152.
101a. Records are vestiges of antiquity and truth. 2 Rolle, 296.
101. TRUTH (See also: ERROR -:- FICTION)

99ee. Alienation pending a suit is void. Branch, Max. 117.
99dd. He who loses the suit should be adjudged to pay the costs thereof to the successful party. C.L.M.; 2 Inst. 289; 3 Bl. Comm. 399; Walton v. Walton, 19 Mo. 668.
99cc. When the plaintiff does not prove his case the defendant is acquitted. Hob. 103.
99bb. An issue (or suit) requires terms of contradiction. To constitute an issue, there must be an affirmative on one side and a negative on the other. Black's, 258; Jenk. Cent. 117.
99aa. No one can sue in the name of another. Dig. 50, 17, 123.
99z. A trial should always be had where the jurors can be the best informed. 7 Coke, lb.

99y. It is for the advantage of the state that there be an end of suits; there should be some period put to litigation. It is for the public good that actions be brought to a close. Jenk. Cent. 61; Co. Litt. 303b; Broom, Max. 331, 343.
99x. An accuser ought not to be heard after the expiration of a reasonable time, unless he can account satisfactorily for the delay. Moore, 817.

99w. Where both parties are equally in fault, the claimant always is at a disadvantage (the condition of the defendant is preferred). Dig. 50, 17, 154; Broom, Max. 644; 1 Story, Contr. 591, 592; Worcester v. Eaton, 11 Mass. 368, 376.
99v. He in vain sues, who cannot prosecute his judgment with effect. Fleta, lib. 6, c. 37, s. 9.
99u. Whichever of two parties has the division, the other has the choice. Co. Litt. 166.
99t. The plaintiff must follow the forum of the thing (property) in dispute, or the forum of the defendant's residence. Branch, Max. 4; Story, Confl. s. 325, k; 2 Kent, Comm. 462.
99s. Where the death of a human being is concerned, [in a matter of life and death,] no delay is [considered] long. Co. Litt. 134.
99r. No one can be held to bail a second time at the suit of the same plaintiff for the same cause of action. C.L.M.
99q. Prescription was instituted that there might be an end to litigation. Dig. 41, 10, 5; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 801.
99p. No one can sue without a writ. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 13, s. 4.
99o. That which is not permitted to the defendant ought not to be to the plaintiff. Dig. 50, 17, 41.
99n. No man can be sued a second time for the same cause of action, if once judgment has been rendered. Broom, Max. 327, 348.
99m. A suit which is based upon a writing ought not to vary from the writing. Jenk. Cent. 65.
99l. No one is bound to arm his adversary. Wing. Max. 665.

99k. A suit is a civil warfare; for as the plaintiffs are armed with actions, and, as it were, girded with swords, so the defendants are fortified with pleas, and are defended, as it were, by shields. Hob. 20; Bract. 339b.
99j. The burden of proof rests on the plaintiff, (or on the party who advances a proposition affirmatively.) Hob. 103; Inst. 2, 20, 4.

99i. The condition or cause of the defendant is better than that of the plaintiff. Broom, Max. 740; Williams v. Ingell, 21 Pick. (Mass.) 289; White v. Franklin Bank, 22 Pick. (Mass.) 186, 187; Cranson v. Gross, 107 Mass. 440, 9 Am. Rep. 45; 4 Inst. 180; Hob. 199.
99h. A case omitted and forgotten is left to the disposal of the common law. 5 Coke, 37; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 45.
99g. One making contradictory allegations is not to be heard. Jenk. Cent. 16; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 160; 4 Inst. 279; Commonwealth v. Pejepscut Prop. 10 Mass. 155, 163.
99f. No one can be at once suitor and judge. Broom, Max. 117.
99e. During a litigation nothing should be changed. Co. Litt. 344; 1 Story, Eq. Jur. s. 406. Secombe v. Steele, 20 How. (61 U.S.) 94, 106.
99d. No prescription runs against a person unable to bring an action. Broom, Max. 903.
99c. A plaintiff is not to be heard who has advanced anything against authority, (or against the rules of law). Black's, 2d. 28; Bouv. 116.
99b. The success of a defendant depends on a perfect case; his loss arises from some defect. 11 Coke, 68a.
99a. A lawsuit signifies every action, whether it be in rem or in personam. Co. Litt. 292.
99. SUITS & TRIALS (See also: EQUITY -:- JUDGMENT -:- LEGAL ACTION)
98g. Where the law does not distinguish, neither ought we to distinguish. 7 Coke, 5b.
98f. Things special take from things general. Halk. Max. 51.
98e. Things general precede, things special follow. Branch, Princ. General things are to be put before particular things. Bouv. 128.
98d. Things general do not derogate from things special. Jenk. Cent. 120. One special statute does not take away from another special statute. Jenk. Cent. 199.
98c. What is general prevails, or is worth as much, among things general, as what is particular among things particular. 11 Coke, 59
98b. When a law is special, but its reason [or object] general, the law is to be understood generally. 2 Inst. 43, 83; 10 Coke, 101.
98a. The specification of one thing is the exclusion of a different thing (or of the rest). Black's, 2d. 430; Matter of Washburn, 4 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 106, 113.
98. SPECIFIC, SPECIAL, GENERAL (See also: AMBIGUITY -:- PRESUME -:- RULES OF LAW)
97n. No example is the same for all purposes. Co. Litt. 212a.
97m. From similars to similars we are to proceed by the same rule. Branch, Princ.
97l. Of things equal, the reason is the same, and the same is the law. Black's, 873.
97k. That which is effectual in one of two like things shall be effectual in the other. Co. Litt. 191a.
97j. Things which agree in substance differ but little. 2 Bulst. 86.
97i. All which is dissimilar, is a difference of degree, the extent of which is ascertained by close and objective analysis. C.L.M.
97h. What is like is not the same; for nothing which is like or similar to another is the same, i.e. no likeness is exact identity. 4 Coke, 18; Co. Litt. 3a; 2 Bl. Comm. 162.
97g. Where the same reason exists, there the same law prevails; and, of things similar the judgment is similar. 7 Coke, 18.
97f. Similar things unite with similar. Bacon, Max; Bouv. 147.

97e. Legal similarity is a similar reason which governs various cases when compared with each other; for what avails in one similar case will avail in the other. Of things dissimilar, the reason is dissimilar. Co. Litt. 191.
97d. Of dissimilars the rule is dissimilar. Co. Litt. 191.
97c. "The same" is always referred to its next antecedent. Co. Litt. 685
97b. That which is similar denotes a partial resemblance only, unless the context indicates otherwise. Black's, 2d. 1089
97a. Things dissimilar ought not to be joined. Jenk. Cent. 24, marg.

96h. One is a servant who is employed by a master to perform service in his affairs and whose physical conduct in performance of the service is controlled by the master. Evans v. Board of Ed. of Hays, 284 P. 2d 1068, 1071.
96g. What ever is acquired by the servant is acquired for the master. C.L.M.
96f. Personal services follow the person. 2 Inst. 374; Fleta, 1, 3, c. 11.
96e. The master or principal shall answer for the acts of his servant or accessory. 4 Inst. 114; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1337.
96d. He is not presumed to consent who obeys the orders of his father or his master. Dig. 50, 17, 4.
96c. Free servants are in general all free persons who let, hire, or engage their services to another. Black's, 2d. 1075.
96b. The master is liable for injury done by his servant. Lofft, 229.
96a. The act of a servant in those things in which he is usually employed, is considered the act of his master. Lofft, 227.
96. SERVANT, SERVICE (See also: AGENT)
95qq. There is no disputing against a man denying principles. Co. Litt. 343

95pp. Every principal thing draws to itself the accessory. Parsons v. Welles, 17 Mass. 425; Green v. Hart, 1 Johns. (N.Y.) 580. The accessory does not draw, but follows its principal. Brooms, Max. 491; Co. Litt. 152a, 389a.
95oo. Use is the master of things; experience is the mistress of things. Co. Litt. 69, 229; Wing. Max. 752.
95nn. That which has not a beginning has not an end. Wing. Max. 79; Co. Litt. 345a.
95mm. The mind submits reluctantly to the rule of law. Hannay v. Eve, 3 Cranch (7 U.S.) 242, 247.
95ll. The inclusion of one is the exclusion of another. The certain designation of one person is an absolute exclusion of all others. 11 Coke, 586.
95kk. That which is more remote does not draw to itself that which is nearer, but the contrary in every case. Co. Litt. 164.
95jj. When there is concurrence of means, he who has chosen one cannot have recourse to another. Bouv. 124.
95ii. The greater number contains in itself the less also. Bract. fol. 16; Dig. 50, 17, 110. The greater always embraces in itself the less. Broom, Max. 174; 5 Coke, 115; Jenk. Cent. 208.
95hh. Frequent interruption does not take away a prescription once secured. 2 Inst. 654.
95gg. The more worthy draws to itself the less worthy. Co. Litt. 43, 355b; Bract. fol. 175; Noy, Max. p. 6, max. 18
95ff. Those are to be esteemed vain fears which do not affect a man of a firm mind. 7 Coke, 27.
95ee. Many things pass with the whole which do not pass separately. Co. Litt. 12a.
95dd. You will perceive many things much more easily by practice than by rules. 4 Inst. 50.
95cc. Precision and certainty are often of more importance to the rules of law than their abstract justice. 9 Wheat. (22 U.S.) 598, 602.
95bb. The law does not arise from the rule (or maxim,) but the rule from the law. Tray. Lat. Max. 384.
95aa. It is better to retrace one's steps than to proceed improperly. 4 Inst. 176.
95z. A negative destroys a negative, and both make an affirmative. Co. Litt. 146b.
95y. Not only what is permitted, but what is convenient, is to be considered, because what is inconvenient is illegal. Co. Litt. 66a.
95x. A consequence should not be drawn from another consequence. Bouv. 121; Bacon, Aph.
95w. What is in suspense is considered as not existing during such suspense. Dig. 50, 17, 169, 1.
95v. Multiplicity and indistinctness produce confusion; and questions, the more simple they are, the more lucid. Hob. 335.
95u. Nothing is invented and perfected at the same moment. Co. Litt. 230; 2 Bl. Comm. 298, note.
95t. Movables follow the law of the person. Story, Confl. Law, s. 638, 639; Broom, Max. 522. Immovable things are governed by the law of locality or place where they are fixed. 2 Kent, Comm. 67.
95s. An integral part being taken away, the whole is taken away. 8 Coke, 41.
95r. Everything contains the element of its own destruction. 2 Inst. 15.
95q. Application is the life of a rule. 2 Bulst. 79.
95p. That is perfect which consists of all its parts. 9 Coke, 9. In the whole the part also is contained. Dig. 50, 17, 113.
95o. That shall be preserved which is useful in the beginning. Dig. 50, 17, 23; Bract. 73b.
95n. The omission of those things which are tacitly implied is of no consequence. 2 Bulst. 131.
95m. He who destroys the means destroys the end. 10 Coke, 51b; Co. Litt. 161a; Shep. Touch. 342. He who gives an end gives the means to that end. Commonwealth v. Andrews, 3 Mass. 129.
95l. In conjunctives each part must be true. Wing. Max. 13.
95k. What avails in the less, will avail in the greater; and what will not avail in the greater, will not avail in the less. Co. Litt. 260.
95j. The foundation being removed, the superstructure fails. Jenk. Cent. 106. Where there is a weak foundation, the work falls. 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 2068; Broom, Max. 169.
95i. It is better to seek the source than to follow the streamlets. Lofft, 606
95h. As to things not apparent, and those not existing, the rule is the same. 5 Coke, 6.
95g. The principle (or beginning) of anything is the most powerful part of a thing. 10 Coke, 49.
95f. There is no reasoning of principles; no argument is required to prove fundamental rules. 2 Bulst. 239.
95e. A general rule is to be understood generally. 6 Coke, 65.
95d. From nothing nothing comes. Jackson v. Waldron, 13 Wend. (N.Y.) 178, 221; Root v. Stuyvesant, 18 Wend. (N.Y.) 257, 301.
95c. There is no rule but what may fail. C.L.M.
95b. Every general principle [or maxim of law] is its own pledge or warrant; and things that are clearly true are not to be proved. Branch, Princ.; Co. Litt. 11.
95a. The word "thing" has a general signification, because it comprehends corporeal and incorporeal objects, of whatever nature, sort, or species. 3 Inst. 182.
95. RULES & PRINCIPLES OF LAW (See also: LAW)
94x. Extraordinary conditions may call for extraordinary remedies. Schechter v. United States, 295 U.S. 495, 528.
94w. Remedies are the life of rights. Campbell v. Holt, 115 U.S. 620, 631.
94v. The judge does not give more than the plaintiff demands. The law gives not more than is demanded. 2 Inst. 286, case 84.
94u. The law wills that, in every case where a man is wronged and endamaged, he shall always have a remedy. Co. Litt. 197b; Branch, Princ.; Broom, Max. 192; Bouv. Inst. 2411.
94t. The law forbids such recoveries whose ends are vain, chargeable, and unprofitable. Co. Litt. 127b.
94s. A new remedy is to be applied to a new case. 2 Inst. 3.
94r. Money being restored does not set free the party offering. Co. Litt. 207.
94q. If you can be relieved by accustomed remedies, new ones should not be tried. 10 Coke, 142.
94p. In similar cases the remedy should be similar. Hardr. 65.
94o. Remedies for rights are ever favorably extended. 18 Vin. Abr. 521; Bouv. 155.
94n. Where the ordinary remedy fails, we must have recourse to what is extraordinary. Black's, 2d. 1002; Bouv. 155; 4 Coke, 92b, 93.
94m. We are never to resort to what is extraordinary as a remedy, until what is ordinary fails. 4 Inst. 84.
94l. No one is considered entitled to recover that which he must give up to another. Dig. 50, 17, 51.
94k. The most favorable construction is to be made in restitutions. Co. Litt. 112.
94j. It is better to restrain or meet a thing in time, than to seek a remedy after a wrong has been inflicted. 2 Inst. 299.
94i. He who cannot pay with his purse must pay in his person, lest he who offends should go unpunished. 2 Inst. 173; 4 Bl. Comm. 20.
94h. It is just that every person is entitled to a certain remedy in the laws for all injuries or wrongs which he may receive in his person, property or character. American Maxim.
94g. Recovery, i.e., restitution, is had by sentence of a judge of a thing wrongfully extorted or detained. Co. Litt. 154a.
94f. Remedy signifies the judicial means for enforcing a right or redressing a wrong. Walters v. City of Ottawa, 88 N.E. 651, 654, 240 III. 259.
94e. To take away all remedy for the enforcement of a right is to take away the right itself. Virginia Coupon Cases, 114 U.S. 270, 303.
94d. If you can be relieved by accustomed remedies, new ones should not be tried. 10 Coke, 142b. If an old wall can be repaired, a new one should not be made. Id.
94c. When the law gives anything, it gives the means of obtaining it (all incidents are tacitly given). 2 Inst. 326; 5 Coke, 47; 3 Kent, Comm. 421; Hob. 234.
94b. That which is without remedy avails of itself, if there be no fault in the party seeking to enforce it. Broom, Max. 212.
94a. Where there is a legal right there is also a legal remedy. 2 Rolle, 17. C.L.M.; Broom, Max. 191, 204; 1 Term. 512; Co. Litt. 197b; 3 Bouv. Inst. n. 2411..
94. REMEDY, RECOVERY(See also: INJURY -:- EQUITY)
93g. That is incident which inseparably belongs to, connected with, or inherent in another thing, called the principal. Black's, 611.
93f. Things incident pass by the grant of the principal. Seymour v. C & N R.R. Co., 25 Barb. (N.Y.) 284, 310.
93e. Things incident cannot be severed. Finch, Law, b. 3, c. 1, n. 12.
93d. Of things relating to each other, one being known, the other is known. Bouv. 155.
93c. Relation shall never make good a void grant or devise of the party. 18 Vin. Abr. 292.
93b. Relation never defeats collateral acts. 18 Vin. Abr. 292.
93a. Relation is a fiction of law, and intended for one thing. 3 Coke, 28
93. RELATION, INCIDENT
92ii. A person may not be punished differently than according to what the sentence enjoins. 3 Inst. 217.
92hh. No one is to be punished for crime or wrong of another. Wing. Max. 336.
92gg. No wise man punishes in order that past things may be recalled, but that future wrongs may be prevented. 2 Bulst. 173.
92ff. Neither punishment nor remedy takes away from the increase which was before. Halk. Max. 126.
92ee. In whatever thing one offends, in that is he rightfully to be punished. [The punishment shall have relation to the nature of the offense.] Co. Litt. 233b; Wing. Max. 204, max. 58
92dd. Let the punishment be proportioned to the crime. Punishment is to be measured by the extent of the offense. Black's, 2d. 305; Branch, Princ.
92cc. Punishment ought not to precede a crime. Halk. Max. 126.
92bb. As transgression is multiplied, the infliction of punishment should increase (Punishment increases with increasing crime). 2 Inst. 479.
92aa. The deprivation of any rights may be punished. Cummings v. Missouri, 4 Wall. (71 U.S.) 277, 320.
92z. It concerns the state that crimes remain not unpunished. Jenk. Cent. pp. 30, 31, case 59; Wing. Max. 501.
92y. The smallest corporal (bodily) punishment is greater than any pecuniary one. 3 Inst. 220.
92x. He threatens the innocent who spares the guilty. 4 Coke, 45.
92w. The punishment due to a crime of which one falsely accuses another should be inflicted upon the perjured informer. C.L.M.
92v. Acting and consenting parties are liable to the same punishment. 5 Coke, 80.
92u. Let not jailers torture or augment the punishment of those intrusted to their keeping; but let the sentence of the law be duly yet mercifully executed. C.L.M.
92t. Where the crime is, there the punishment should be also. C.L.M.; 6 Coke, 47.
92s. The intention is punished although the intended result does not follow. 9 Coke, 55.
92r. He who sins when drunk shall be punished when sober. Broom, Max. 17.
92q. He who spares the guilty punishes the innocent. Jenk. Cent. 133.
92p. That the punishment may reach a few, but the fear of it affect all. 4 Inst. 6; 4 Bl. Comm. 11.
92o. A delinquent provoked by anger ought to be punished more mildly. 3 Inst. 55.
92n. No one is punished unless for some wrong, act, or default. 2 Inst. 287
92m. A fine does not impose a loss of reputation or character. Code. 1, 54.
92l. One confessing willingly should be dealt with more leniently. 4 Inst. 66; Branch, Princ.
92k. Good men hate sin through love of virtue; bad men, through fear of punishment. Black's, 2d. 847.
92j. 3d Lond. ed. 279. The law punishes falsehood. Jenk. Cent. 15.
92i. No one is punished for his thoughts. Dig. 48, 19, 18; Broom, Max.
92h. Death is called the "last punishment," the "extremity of punishment." 3 Inst. 212. The most extreme punishment we consider to be is death. Dig. 48, 19, 21.
92g. Infamy arises from crime, not from its punishment. C.L.M.
92f. Punishment adheres to the offense. Peoria Gas & Elec. Co. v. Peoria, 200 U.S. 48, 56.
92e. No one is to be punished twice for the same offense. C.L.M.; 4 Coke, 43; 11 Coke, 59b.
92d. Those sinning secretly are punished more severely than those sinning openly. 8 Coke, 127.
92c. A prison is established not for the sake of punishment, but of detention and guarding. Co. Litt. 260a; Lofft, 119.
92b. Crimes are more effectually prevented by the certainty than by the severity of punishment. C.L.M.
92a. Agents and abettors are punished alike. C.L.M.
92. PUNISHMENT (See also: CRIME -:- JUSTICE)
91ll. He has better title who was first in point of time. Co. Litt. 14a.
91kk. It is one thing to possess; it is another to be in possession. Hob. 163; Bract. 206.
91jj. Things which are taken from enemies immediately become the property of the captors. C.L.M.
91ii. Things taken or captured by pirates and robbers do not change their ownership. 1 Kent, Comm. 108, 184.
91hh. The legal conception of property is of right. Leroy Fibre Co. v. Chicago M. & St. P. Ry., 232 U.S. 340, 350.
91gg. Not right but seizin (possession) makes the stock. C.L.M.
91ff. The risk lies upon the owner of the subject. Tray. Lat. Max. 114.
91ee. No man is compelled to sell his own property, even for a just price. 4 Inst. 275.
91dd. Two cannot possess or own one thing in entirety. Co. Litt. 368; Dig. 13, 6, 5, 15; Bract. fol. 28b.
91cc. A person in possession is not bound to prove that the possessions belong to him. Broom, Max. 714.

91bb. The right of property is that sole and despotic dominion which one man claims and exercises over the external things of the world, in total exclusion of the right of any other individual. 1 Bl. Comm. 138; 2 Bl. Comm. 2, 5.
91aa. No one can grant or convey what he does not own. Seymour v. Canandaigua & N.F.R. Co., 25 Barb. (N.Y.) 284, 301. Fassett v. Smith, 23 N.Y. 252.
91z. That which is mine cannot be lost, transferred to another, or taken away without my own act, consent, or forfeiture. Broom, Max. 465; Jenk. Cent. p. 251, case 41; 8 Coke, 92; Dig. 50, 17, 11.
91y. Rights of dominion are transferred without title or delivery, by prescription, to-wit, long and quiet possession. Co. Litt. 113.
91x. When a man has the possession as well as the right of property, he is said to have jus duplicatum—a double right, forming a complete title. Bract. lib. 4, tr. 4, c. 4; 2 Bl. Comm. 199, 311.
91w. Possession is a good title where no better title appears. 20 Vin. Abr. 278; Bouv. 148.
91v. A title is the just right of possessing that which is our own. C.L.M.
91u. Long possession produces the right of possession, and takes away from the true owner his action. Co. Litt. 110b, 115a; Fleta, lib. 3, c. 15, s. 6; Branch, Princ.; Co. Litt. 6.
91t. A title is the just right of possession that which is our own; it is so called from "tuendo,," defending. 8 Coke, 153.
91s. No one should lose his property without his act or negligence. Co. Litt. 263.
91r. Every one is the regulator and disposer of his own property. Co. Litt. 223a.
91q. Neither disease, indigence, nor any evil of the same kind is more contrary to nature than appropriating or desiring to appropriate the property of another to our own use. C.L.M.
91p. Chattels are considered in law among the minor things. Jenk. Cent. 52.
91o. Nothing is so consonant to natural equity as to regard the will of the owner in transferring his own property to another. 1 Coke, 100; Inst. 2, 1, 40.
91n. One is not considered as acquiring property in a thing which he is bound to restore. Dig. 50, 17, 51; Dig. 50, 17, 139, 1.
91m. That does not truly belong to one which can be taken from him upon occasion. Dig. 50, 17, 159, 1.
91l. Things abandoned [or which belong to no one] become the property of the first occupant. Taylor v. The Cato, 1 Pet. Adm. 53, Fed. Case. No. 13,786; Dig. 41, 1, 3; 2 Bl. Comm. 258.
91k. When the parties are equally wrong or equal in right, the condition of the party in possession is the better. Plowd. 296; Broom, Max. 71; 4 Bouv. Inst. n. 3724.
91j. There is no prescription for that which is not possessed. Cycl. Dict. 693
91i. Prescription is a title by authority of law, deriving its force from use and time. Co. Litt. 113.
91h. Chattels justly possessed cannot be lost. Jenk. Cent. 28.
91g. A destruction of the thing is the loss of its owner. 2 Bouv. Inst. nn. 1456, 1466; Story, Bailm. 426; 2 Kent, Comm, 591.
91f. A deprivation presupposes a possession. 2 Rolle, 419.
91e. It is unjust that freemen should not have the free disposal of their own property. Co. Litt. 223a; 4 Kent, Comm. 131; Hob. 87.
91d. When the question is as to the gain of two persons, the cause or title of the party in possession is the better one. Dig. 50, 17, 126.
91c. The touching or removing of another's property, with an intention of stealing, is theft. Jenk. Cent. 132.
91b. He cannot be considered as having ceased to have a thing, who never had it. Dig. 50. 17. 208.
91a. It is not incumbent on the possessor of property to prove his right to his possessions. Code. 4.9.2; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 639.
91. PROPERTY RIGHTS & POSSESSION (See also: LAND -:- LEGAL RIGHTS -:- INHERITANCE)
90f. If the object is to regulate a thing it cannot be prohibited, for the power to regulate is not the power to prohibit. C.L.M.
90e. Law is a sacred sanction, commanding what is right, and prohibiting the contrary. 2 Inst. 587.
90d. If one has the power to prohibit or prevent a thing but does not, it is as though he did the thing himself. 2 Inst. 146; 3 Inst. 158.
90c. What is prohibited in the nature of things can be confirmed by no law. Finch, Law, 74.
90b. When anything is prohibited, everything by which it is reached is prohibited also. 2 Inst. 48; Wing. Max. 618; Livingston v. Harris, 11 Wend. (N.Y.) 329.
90a. When anything is prohibited directly, it is prohibited also indirectly. Co. Litt. 223.
90. PROHIBIT (See also: GRANTS)
89m. A quality which ought to form a part is easily presumed. Black's, 2d. 973.
89l. Presumptions are conjectures from probable proof, assumed for purposes of evidence. C.L.M.
89k. No impossible or dishonorable things are to be presumed; but only things true, honorable, and possible. Co. Litt. 78.
89j. The presumption is always in favor of the one who denies. 10 Clark & F. 534.
89i. That which ought to be done is easily presumed. Halk. Max. 153.
89h. No thing unjust is to be presumed in law. 4 Coke, 72.
89g. Odious and dishonest acts are not presumed in law. Co. Litt. 78; Jackson v. Miller, 6 Wend. (N.Y.) 228, 231, 21 Am. Dec. 316; Nichols v. Pinner, 18 N.Y. 295, 300.
89f. All things are presumed to have been rightly and regularly done. Co. Litt. 232b; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 847.
89e. A presumption will stand good until the contrary is proved. Hob. 297; 3 Bl. Comm. 371; In re Blake's Will, 120 A.2d 745, 749.
89d. In favor of life, liberty, and innocence, all things are to be presumed. Lofft, 125.
89c. Strong presumption is of weight in law. Jenk. Cent. p. 56, case 3.
89b. Strong presumption is full proof. Co. Litt. 6b.
89a. Presumptions arise from what generally happens. Post v. Pearsall, 22 Wend. (N.Y.) 425, 475.
89. PRESUME, PRESUMPTION
88p. Subsequent laws repeal prior conflicting ones. 2 Rolle, 410; 11 Coke, 626, 630.
88o. It is perilous to introduce new and untried things [laws]. Co. Litt. 379a

88n. The doctrine of stare decisis, commonly called the `doctrine of precedents,' means that we should adhere to decided cases and settled principles and not disturb matters which have been established by judicial determination. Johnson v. Western Union Tele. Co. (N.C.) 57 S.E. 122, 124.
88m. Let it be done as it has used to be done, (nothing must be rashly innovated.] Jenk Cent. 116, case 39; Branch, Princ.
88l. Antiquity did nothing without a good reason. Co. Litt. 65. Thus, nothing should be rashly changed. Jenk. Cent. 163.
88k. Precedents are principles of law which are also conclusions, or decision in a cause; and not a process of reasoning or illustration or analogy. Rodwell v. Rowland, (N.C.) 50 S.E. 319, 327.
88j. The old way is the safe way. Ex parte Crane, 5 Peters (30 U.S.) 223. The beaten road is the safest. 10 Coke, 142.
88i. One absurdity being allowed [established as precedent], an infinity follow. 1 Coke, 102.
88h. We are to adhere to precedents, and not to unsettled things which are not established. Yates vs. Lansing, 9 Johns. (N.Y.) 395, 428; Moore vs. Lyons, 25 Wend. (N.Y.) 119, 142.
88g. Things which are tolerated on account of necessity ought not to be drawn into precedent. Dig. 50, 17, 162.
88f. Later laws prevail over those which preceded them. Dig. 1, 4, 4. Later laws abrogate prior laws that are contrary to them. Broom, Max. 27, 29.
88e. Things introduced contrary to the reason of law ought not to be drawn into a precedent. 12 Coke, 75; Dig. 1,3, 14; Dig. 50, 17.
88d. A particular case, left unprovided for by statute, must be disposed of according to the law as it existed prior to such statute. Broom, Max. 46.
88c. It is best not to unsettle things which are originally established. Green v. Hudson River R. Co., 28 Barb. (N.Y.) 9, 22.
88b. Precedents have as much law as justice. Bouv. 149.
88a. It is not a new thing that prior statutes shall give place to later ones. Dig. 1. 3. 26; 1. 1. 4; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed 27.
88. PRECEDENT (See also: JUDGMENT -:- TIME)
87o. An ambiguous plea ought to be interpreted against the party pleading it. Co. Litt. 303b; Bacon, Max. reg. 3.
87n. When the order of pleading is observed, the law also is observed. Co. Litt. 303a; Broom, Max. 188.
87m. It sometimes happens that a plea which seems prima facie just, nevertheless is injurious and unequal. Inst. 4,14, 1, 2.
87l. Pleas [i.e., actions] are personal, real, and mixed. Co. Litt. 284.
87k. The defendant by a plea becomes plaintiff. Best, Er. 294, s. 252.

87j. Whatever is offered by the defendant as sufficient to defeat the cause of action stated in the plaintiff's declaration, either by way of denial, justification, or confession, is a plea. Jewett Car Co. v. Kirkpatrick, 107 Fed. 622, 624.

87i. Two negative pleas do not form an issue. Lofft, 415. 2 Chase—The liberty of hunting, one's self, and keeping protected against all other persons, deer and beasts of the forest, without regard to the ownership of land.
87h. He who does not deny, admits. (A well-known rule of pleading.) Tray. Leg. Max. 503.
87g. He is defeated by the plea that the action have been assigned. Cheesebrough v. Millard, 1 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 409, 414.
87f. An alternative petition is not to be heard. 5 Coke, 40.
87e. Words make the plea. 5 Mod. 458.
87d. There can be no plea against an action which destroys the matter of the plea. Jenk. Cent. 106, case 2.
87c. A false plea is the basest of all things. Bouv. 126.
87b. A plea denying a fact is the last of all. Black's, 2d. 457.
87a. A plea of a matter of which a dissolution is sought by the action is null. Jenk. Cent. 37, case 71; Bacon, Max. reg. 2.
86q. A personal right of action dies with the person. Noy, Max. 14.
86p. A chase is by common law. 2 Bl. Comm. 414-416.
86o. When two rights meet in one person, it is the same as if they were in two persons. Black's, 2d. 305.
86n. Rivers and ports are public. Therefore the right of fishing there is common to all. Day. Ir. KB. 55; Branch, Princ.

86m. No right is held more sacred, or is more carefully guarded by the common law, than the right of every individual to the possession and control of his own person, free from all restraint or interference of others, unless by clear or unquestionable authority of law. Union Pac. Ry. v. Botsford, 141 U.S. 250, 251.
86l. No one can transfer to another a greater right than he himself has. Co. Litt. 309; Wing. Max. 56; 2 Kent, Comm. 324; 35 U.S. 161, 175.
86k. No one is considered to act with guile, or to be a wrong-doer, who uses his own right. Dig. 50, 17, 55; Broom, Max. 130; Amer. Ins. Co. v. Griswold, 14 Wend. (N.Y.) 399, 492.
86j. The right of blood and kindred cannot be destroyed by any civil law. Dig. 50, 17, 9; Bacon, Max. reg. 11; Broom, Max. 533; Jackson v. Phillips, 14 Allen (Mass.) 562.
86i. He is not deemed to use force who exercises his own right, and proceeds by ordinary action. Dig. 50, 17, 155, 1.
86h. A right not vested in a person living, but merely exists in the consideration and contemplation of law, is said to be in abeyance. Co. Litt. 342.
86g. There is no doubt that the rights of others [third parties] cannot be prejudiced by private agreements. Dig. 2, 15, 3, pr.; Broom, Max. 697.
86f. Right is threefold,—of property, of possession, and of possibility. Black's, 681.
86e. A thing is private which is not common. Le Breton v. Miles, 8 Paige, Ch. (N.Y.) 261, 270.
86d. Rights never die. Bouv. 156.
86c. If a person neglect to insist on his right, he is deemed to have abandoned it. C.L.M.
86b. No man can forfeit another's right. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 28, s. 11.
86a. It would be idle and trite to say that no right is absolute. Orient Ins. Co. v. Draggs, 172 U.S. 557, 566.
86. PERSONAL RIGHTS (See also: LEGAL RIGHTS -:- PROPERTY RIGHTS)
85i. Where a thing is owned in common or shared equally, it is agreed that the cause of him prohibiting its use is the better. Dig. 10, 3, 28; 3 Kent, Comm. 45; 16 Johns. (N.Y.) 438, 491.
85h. A partnership is moreover dissolved by the death of a partner. Inst. 3, 26, 5; Dig. 17, 2.
85g. Several part-owners are as one body, by reason of the unity of their rights. Co. Litt. 164.
85f. In a partnership the condition of one who forbids is the more favorable. Black's, 607.
85e. The partner of my partner is not my partner. Dig. 50, 17, 47, 1.
85d. One co-proprietor can exercise no authority over the common property against the will of the other. Dig. 10, 3, 28.

85c. When the subject is extinguished, the incident ceases. Thus, when the business for which a partnership has been formed is completed, or brought to an end, the partnership itself ceases. Inst. 3, 26, 6; Kent, Comm. 52, note; Griswold v. Waddington, 16 Johns. (N.Y.) 438, 489.
85b. When any partner renounces the partnership, the partnership is dissolved. Tray. Leg. Max. 118.
85a. No one should be retained in a partnership against his will. Selden v. Vermilya, 2 Sandf. (N.Y.) 568, 593; United Ins. Co. v. Scott, 1 Johns. (N.Y.) 106, 114.
85. PARTNERSHIP
84m. The form of taking oaths differs in language, yet the meaning of all is the same, for all oaths ought to have this sense: that the Deity is invoked. Bouv. 134.
84l. An oath made between others ought neither hurt nor profit. 4 Inst. 279.
84k. No one is believed in court but upon his oath. 3 Inst. 79; C.L.M.
84j. To swear is to call God to witness, and is an act of religion. 3 Inst. 165; Cycl. Dict. 566.
84i. An infamous person is repelled or prevented from taking an oath. Co. Litt. 158; Bract. fol. 185.
84h. In law, none is credited unless he is sworn. All facts must, when established by witnesses, be under oath or affirmation. Cro. Car. 64; Bouv. 130.
84g. A foolish oath, though false, makes not perjury. 2 Inst. 167.
84f. Every oath ought to be founded on certain knowledge. 4 Inst. 279.
84e. An oath has in it three component parts,—truth, justice, and judgment; truth in the party swearing; justice and judgment in the judge administering the oath. 3 Inst. 160.
84d. An oath is indivisible; it is not to be held partly true and partly false. 4 Inst. 274; Bouv. 134.
84c. Punishment is due if the words of an oath be false. Black's, 840.
84b. It is immaterial whether a man gives his assent by words or by acts and deeds. 10 Coke, 52.
84a. There is no stronger link or bond between men than an oath. Jenk. Cent. Cas. 126; Id. p. 126, case 54.
84. OATHS
83l. What is introduced of necessity is never introduced except when necessary. 2 Rolle, 512.
83k. Things which are admitted on the ground of necessity ought not to be drawn into question. Dig. 50, 17, 162.
83j. The rights of necessity are a part of the law. C.L.M.; Plowd. 18.
83i. The law of necessity is the law of the time and of place; that is, of the instant, or present moment. Hob. 159; 1 Hale, P.C. 54.
83h. Necessity overrules the law. Hob. 144; Cooley, Const, Lim. (4th Ed.) 747. Necessity shall be a good excuse in our law, and in every other law. Plowd. 18a.
83g. In cases of extreme necessity, everything is in common. Hale, P. C. 54.
83f. That which necessity compels, it justifies. Hale, P.C. 54.
83e. Nothing is more just than that which is necessary. Day. Ir. KB. 12; Branch, Princ.
83d. That which is otherwise not permitted, necessity permits; and necessity makes a privilege as to private rights. Bacon, Max.
83c. Necessity makes that lawful which otherwise is not lawful. 10 Coke, 61; 2 Inst. 326; Fleta, lib. 5, c. 23, s. 14.
83b. What is necessary is lawful. Jenk. Cent. p. 76, case 45. Thus, necessity knows no law. C.L.M.
83a. A good thing required by necessity is not good beyond the limits of the necessity. Hob. 144
83. NECESSITY, NECESSARY

82h. Natural rights are such as appertain to man, inherent in his nature or plainly assured by natural law, being distinguished from such as are created by law, and depend upon civilized society. Borden v. State, 11 Ark. 519, 527; 44 Am. Dec. 217.
82g. By natural right, anyone is entitled to summon another into court. Branch, Max. 120.
82f. The law favors common right. Wing. Max. p. 547, max. 144.
82e. Natural right is that which has the same force among all men. 7 Coke, 12.
82d. He is justified who acts in pure defense of his own life or limb, for it is a natural right to do so. C.L.M.
82c. A dispensation is a wound, because it wounds a common right. Day. 69; Branch, Princ.
82b. Every right is either made by consent, or is constituted by necessity, or is established by custom, or created in us by the decrees of Providence. Dig. 1, 3, 40.
82a. Self-defense is the primary law of nature. C.L.M. Whatever one does in defense of his person, that he is considered to have done legally. 2 Inst. 590.
82. NATURAL RIGHTS (See also: FREEDOM -:- PERSONAL RIGHTS)
81k. Calling things by the same name does not obliterate the differ ences between them. Cincinnati R.R. v. Kentucky, 115 U.S. 321, 337.

81j. The presence of the body cures error in the name; the truth of the body cures error in the name; the truth of the name cures an error in the description. Broom, Max. 637, 639, 640; Bacon, Max. reg. 25; 6 Term. 675.
81i. The names of things ought to be understood, not according to the opinion of individuals, but according to common usage. Dig. 33, 10, 7, 2.
81h. If you know not the names of things, the knowledge of things themselves perishes; and, if you lose the names, the distinction of the things is certainly lost. Co. Litt. 86.
81g. Names are mutable, but things are immutable. A name may be true or false, or may change, but the thing itself always maintains its identity. 6 Coke, 66.
81f. The thing is named from its principal part. 5 Coke, 47.
81e. Initials are no legal part of a name, the authorities holding the full Christian name to be essential. Monroe Cattle Co. v. Becker, 147 U.S. 47, 58.
81d. Names are the notes of things. 11 Coke, 20. Names are the symbols of things. Godb; Bouv. 142.
81c. A name is not sufficient if a thing or subject for it does not exist by law or by fact. 4 Coke, 107b.
81b. An error as to a name is nothing when there is certainty as to the person or thing. 11 Coke, 21; Broom, Max. 634; 2 Kent, Comm. 292.
81a. A name is accepted if it errs not in substance. 6 Coke, 66.
81. NAME
80i. A delinquent provoked by anger ought to be punished more mildly. 3 Inst. 55.
80h. A minor is not bound to reply during his minority, except as a matter of favor in a cause of dower. 3 Bulst. 143.
80g. The law aids minors. Jenk. Cent. case 97. A minor is to be aided as youth is liable to err. Jenk. Cent. case 47.
80f. A minor who is under twelve years of age cannot be outlawed, nor placed without the law, because before such age he is not under any law, nor in decennary. Co. Litt. 128.
80e. A infant is not supposed to be able to suffer, i.e., to do an act to his own prejudice. Dig. 50, 17, 110, 2.
80d. A minor before majority cannot act in a case of property, nor even agree. 2 Inst. 291.
80c. A minor ought not to be guardian to a minor. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 10; Co. Litt. 88b.
80b. A minor cannot make an oath. Co. Litt. 172b. A minor cannot be sworn on a jury. Litt. 289.
80a. A minor can make his own condition better, but by no means worse. Co. Litt. 337.
80. MINOR, JUVENILE

79q. Consent, and not cohabitation, makes the marriage; and persons cannot consent to marriage before marriageable years. 5 Coke, 80; 6 Coke, 22; 1 Bl. Comm 434; Co. Litt. 33a; Dig. 50, 17, 30; 1 Bouv. Inst. 103.
79p. Subsequent marriage cures preceding criminality. Black's, 2d. 766.

79o. All things which are the wife's are the husband's. Bract. fol. 32; 2 Kent, Comm. 130-143. Although the property may be the wife's, the husband is the keeper of it, since he is the head of the wife. Co. Litt. 112.
79n. The father is he whom the marriage points out. 1 Bl. Comm. 446; Tate v. Penne, 7 Mart. (N.S. La.) 48, 553; Dig. 2, 4, 5; Broom, Max. 516; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 273, 304.
79m. Legitimacy is the lawful consequence of lawful marriage. Gaines v. Relf, 53 U.S. 472, 595.
79l. The presumption is always in favor of the validity of a marriage. Black's, 1070.
79k. Wife and son are names of nature. 4 Bacon's Works, 350.
79j. A wife is not her own mistress, but is under the power of her husband. 5 Inst. 108.
79i. Husband and wife are considered one person (as one flesh and blood) in law. Co. Litt. 112; Jenk. Cent. 27.
79h. A wife follows the domicile of her husband. Tray. Lat. Max. 606.
79g. Insanity prevents marriage from being contracted, because consent is needed. 1 Bl. Comm. 439.
79f. The union of male and female is founded on the law of nature. 7 Coke, 13; Black's, 246.
79e. A sentence against marriage never becomes a matter finally adjudged (never conclusive upon the parties). 7 Coke, 43.
79d. Marriages ought to be free. 2 Kent, Comm. 102; Halk. Max. 86.
79c. The male sex always includes the female. Dig. 32, 62.
79b. Divorce is called from divertendo, because a man is diverted from his wife. Co. Litt. 234.
79a. It is not lawful to have two wives at the same time. Inst. 1, 10, 6; 1 Bl. Comm. 436.
79. MARRIAGE (See also: INHERITANCE -:- DOWER)
78n. It is not lawful to do evil that good may come of it. 11 Coke, 74a; Ex parte Curtis, 106 U.S. 371, 378.
78m. Evil deeds are distinguished from evil purposes. Jenk. Cent. 290.
78l. Evil has not an efficient, but a deficient cause. 3 Inst. Proeme.
78k. The malicious plans of men must be avoided. 4 Coke, 15.
78j. Malice supplies age. 1 Bl. Comm. 464.
78i. When any thing by itself is not evil, and yet may be an example for evil, it is not to be done. 2 Inst. 564.
78h. An evil custom is to be abolished. Co. Litt. 141.
78g. That part is bad which accords not with its whole. Plowd. 161.
78f. Good laws arise from evil manners, i.e., are necessitated by the evil behavior of men. 2 Inst. 161.
78e. He who is once bad is presumed to be always so in the same degree. Cro. Car. 317; Best, Ev. 345.
78d. The more common the evil, the worse it is. Branch, Princ.
78c. Evil is not presumed. 4 Coke, 72; Branch, Princ. Nothing wicked is to be presumed. Cycl. Dict. 693
78b. Malice is sour, it is the quality of a bad mind. 2 Bulst. 49.
78a. Evil deeds ought not to remain unpunished, and impunity affords continual incitement to the delinquent. 4 Coke, 45.
78. MALICE, EVIL, BAD(See also: CORRUPT ACTS -:- WRONG)
77u. The right ascends collaterally. Bract. 20.
77t. A fact does not necessarily constitute a right. Branch, Max. 15.
77s. He will not be considered as using force who exercises his rights and proceeds by forms of law. Dig. 50, 17, 155, 1.
77r. He who has the right to elect to do a thing has also the right to refuse it. C.L.M.
77q. No one can be made to testify against himself or betray himself. C.L.M. Broom, Max. 968. No one is bound to accuse himself, except before God. Wing. Max. 486; Hardr. 139; 1 Bl. Comm. 443.
77p. Any one may waive or renounce the benefit of a principle or rule of law that exists only for his protection. Black's, 304.
77o. It is the right of the accused to be tried by a legally constituted court, not by a kangaroo court. Williams v. U.S., 341 US 97, 101.
77n. A continual usage is of great effect to establish a right. 4 Coke, 78; Wing. Max. p. 719, max. 192.
77m. Mistaken notions about one's legal rights are not sufficient to bar prosecution for crime. Williams v. North Carolina, 325 U.S. 238.
77l. No one is bound to expose himself to misfortune and dangers. Co. Litt. 253.
77k. No one is bound to swear to the fact of his own criminality; no one can be forced to give his own oath in evidence of his guilt, or testify to his own baseness. Halk. Max. 100; Cycl. Dict. 690.
77j. No man is bound to produce writings against himself. Black's, 815.

77i. He who has the legal right to do the greater or more important act shall not be debarred from the lesser act. 4 Coke, 23; Dig. 50, 17, 21; Broom, Max. 176; Co. Litt. 355b; 2 Inst. 307; Noy, Max. 26.
77h. A right cannot arise from a wrong. 4 Bingh. 639; Bouv. 134.
77g. Right cannot die. Jenk. Cent. 100, case 95.
77f. No freeman shall be deprived of life, liberty or property but by the lawful judgment of his peers, or by the law of the land—that is by the common law. C.L.M.
77e. Whose right it is to institute, his right it is to abrogate. Broom, Max. 878, note.
77d. Every one may renounce or relinquish a right introduced for his own benefit. 2 Inst. 183; Wing. Max. p. 483, max. 123; 4 Bl. Comm. 317; The People v. Van Rensselaer, 9 N.Y. 291, 333.
77c. He who uses his legal rights harms no one. Carson v. Western R. Co., 8 Gray (Mass.) 424; Broom, Max. 379.
77b. It is allowable to kill a thief if he cannot otherwise be taken. C.L.M.
77a. No one should be twice harassed for the same offense. C.L.M.; The People v. Mercein, 3 Hill (N.Y.) 420; 30 U.S. 61.
77. LEGAL RIGHTS (See also: PERSONAL RIGHTS)
76m. Capacity relates to soundness of mind or a mind that has full and intelligent knowledge of an act engaged in. In re Null's Estate, 153 A. 137, 139, 302 Pa. 64.
76l. Women are not admissible to public offices. Jenk. Cent. 237. Women are excluded from all civil and public charges or offices. Dig. 50, 17, 2; 1 Exch. 645; 6 Mees. & W. 216.
76k. No one can claim another's status as his own merely because he wishes it. C.L.M.
76j. Towns and boroughs [municipal corporations] act as if persons. Warner v. Beers, 23 Wend. (N.Y.) 103, 144.
76i. No one is bound to incapacitate himself. Jenk. Cent. 40.
76h. A person is a man considered with reference to a certain status. Bouv. 147.
76g. No one can make his condition better by his own misdeed. Dig. 50, 17, 134, 1.
76f. A status, once established, is presumed by the law to remain until the contrary appears or is expressed. Kidder v. Stevens, 60 Cal. 414, 419.
76e. An infant does not differ much from a lunatic [in legal capacity.] Bract. 1. 3, c. 2, s. 8; Dig. 50, 17, 5, 40; 1 Story, Eq. Jur. ss. 223, 224, 242.

76d. Legal capacity is the attribute of a person's ability, qualification, or legal power or right to perform civil acts, assume duties, and to hold lands. Sargent v. Burdett, 96 Ga. 111, 22 S.E. 667.
76c. Legal status is a condition of a person, such as being an infant, a slave, a married man or woman, a ward, or a prisoner. Redmon v. Leach, 130 S.W.2d 873, 876.
76b. The status of a person is his legal position or condition. Black's, 2d 1107; Barney v. Tourtellotte, 138 Mass. 108.
76a. A speech relating to the person is to be understood as relating to his condition or status. 4 Coke, 16.
76. LEGAL CAPACITY & STATUS (See also: MINOR -:- GUARDIAN)
75aa. A right of action can not arise out of fraud. Cowp. 343; Broom, Max. 729.
75z. No prescription runs against one who is unable to bring an action. C.L.M.
75y. The end of litigation is justice. U. P. Ry. v. Botsford, 141 US 258.
75x. No one is bound to arm his adversary. Wing. Max. 665.

75w. When the foundation fails, all goes to the ground; as, where the cause of action fails, the action itself must of necessity fail. Wing. Max., 113, 114, max. 40; Broom, Max. 180; Noy, Max. 5, max. 12. (7 2)
75v. Death dissolves all things [in legal actions.] Jenk. Cent. p. 160, case 2. A personal action dies with the person. Noy, Max. 14.
75u. A matter, the validity of which is at issue in legal proceedings, cannot be set up as a bar [impediment] thereto. Bac. Max. reg. 2.
75t. In civil matters agency (or service) excuses, but not so in criminal matters. Lofft. 228; Tray. Leg. Max. 243.
75s. Every man is liable to be sued wrongfully or without cause. Dow v. Johnson, 10 Otto (100 U.S.) 158, 193.
75r. No one is bound to accuse himself. Wing. Max. 486; 1 Bl. Comm. 443.
75q. In every action where two distresses concur, that is, in rem and in personam, that is to be chosen which is most dreaded, and which binds most firmly. Bract. fol. 372; Fleta, 1. 6, c. 14, s. 28.
75p. When an action is merely criminal, it can be instituted from the beginning either criminally or civilly. Bract. 102.
75o. That which is not permitted to the defendant should not be to the plaintiff. Dig. 50, 17, 41.
75n. The action in personam is that by which we sue him who is under obligation to us to do something or give something. Dig. 44, 7, 25; Bract. 101b.
75m. No action arises out of an immoral consideration. 2 Peters (27 U.S.) 539, Cycl. Dict. 375.
75l. Every plaint and every action for injuries is limited within certain times. Co. Litt. 1146.
75k. Every action is a plaint or complaint. Co. Litt. 292a.
75j. He who has once relinquished or renounced his action cannot bring it again. 8 Coke, 59a.
75i. No one maintains an action arising out of his own wrong. Broom, Max. 297.
75h. A fine puts an end to litigation. 3 Inst. 78.
75g. No one is prohibited from making use of several defenses. Co. Litt. 304a; Wing. Max. 479.
75f. Every action proceeds in its own course. Jenk. Cent. 77.
75e. An action is not given to one who is not injured. Jenk. Cent. 69.
75d. Not guilty unless the intent be guilty. 1 Story, Cont. 4th ed. 87.
75c. No one goes to law without an action, and no one can bring an action without a writ or bill. Bract. fol. 112; Fleta, 1.2, c. 13, s. 4.
75b. The action in rem is that by which we seek our property which is possessed by another, and is always against him who possesses the property. Dig. 44, 7, 25; Bract. fol. 102.
75a. When an action is brought to annul a proceeding, the defendant cannot plead such proceeding in bar. Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 154; Wing. Max. 647.
75. LEGAL ACTION & PROCEEDINGS, (See also: JUDICIAL ACTS -:- PLEAS -:- SUITS)

74l. That which natural reason has established among all men, is call the law of nations. Dig. 1,1, 9; Inst. 1, 2, 1; 1 Bl. Comm. 43. 74m. The law regards the order of nature. Co. Litt. 197b. 74n. Nature covets perfection; so does law also. Hob. 144.
74k. Crimes against nature are the most heinous. 3 Inst. 20.
74j. Things which are forbidden by the nature of things are confirmed by no law. Branch, Princ. Positive laws are framed after the laws of nature and reason. Finch, Law. 74.
74i. Nature makes no leap, nor does the law. Co. Litt. 238.
74h. The force of nature is greatest. 2 Inst. 564.
74g. Nature takes little heed. Vandenheuvel v. United Ins. Co., 2 Johns. Cas. (N.Y.) 127, 166.
74f. Jus naturale, or natural law, has its foundation in the will of God. 1 Bl. Comm. 39; 1 Kent, Comm. 2, note; Id. 4 note.
74e. No one is presumed to do anything against nature. 22 Vin. Abr. 154; Bouv. 142
74d. The laws of nature are most perfect and immutable; but in the condition of human laws there is nothing which can continue perpetually. 7 Coke, 25.
74c. The laws of nature are unchangeable. Cycl. Dict. 566; Branch, Princ.
74b. The Law respects the bonds of nature. Wing. Max. p. 268, max. 78; Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, no. 29.
74a. When laws imposed by the state fail, we must act by the law of nature. 2 Rolle, 298; Bouv. 136.
74. LAW OF NATURE
73k. The principle distinction between the terms `lawful' and `legal' is that the former contemplates the substance of law, the latter the form of law. Black's, 703.
73j. That which is lawful is constituted or authorized by law; rightful; conformable to law; allowed by law; legitimate; competent. Ohio Auto. Spr. Co. v. Fender, 141 N.E. 269, 275.
73i. It has been said, with much truth, "Where the law ends, tyranny begins." Merritt v. Welsh, 14 Otto (104 U.S.) 694, 702.
73h. That which is or lawful in the less shall be lawful in the greater; and that which is not lawful in the greater shall neither be lawful in the less. Co. Litt. 260a; 8 Coke, 48.
73g. Nothing that is inconvenient is lawful. Co. Litt. 66a, 97b.
73f. There are some things which are not proper though lawful; but certainly those things are not proper which are not lawful. Hob. 159.
73e. Nothing that is against reason is lawful. Co. Litt. 97b.
73d. It is lawful to repel force by force, provided it be done with the moderation of blameless defense, not for the purpose of taking revenge, but to ward off injury. Co. Litt. 162a.
73c. We are able to do that which we can do lawfully. Bouv. 129.
73b. To investigate [inquire into] is the way to know what things are truly lawful. Litt. s. 443; Bouv. 150.
73a. Under pretext of legality, what is illegal ought not to be admitted. Wing. Max. p. 728, max. 196.
73. LAWFUL, UNLAWFUL (See also: ANNUL -:- INVALID)
72n. He vainly invokes the aid of the law who transgresses the law. Fleta, lib. 4, c. 2, s. 3; 2 Hale, P.C. 386; Broom, Max. 279, 297.
72m. Laws are made to no purpose, except for those that are subject and obedient. Branch, Princ.; 7 Coke, 13.
72l. The law compels no one to show that which he is presumed not to know. Lofft, 569.
72k. The law compels no one to do vain or useless things. Co. Litt. 197b, 319; Broom, Max. 252; 5 Coke, 21a; Wing. Max. 600; 3 Bl. Comm. 144; Watmough v. Francis, 7 Penn. St. 206, 214.
72j. He who adheres to the letter of the law adheres to its bark. Co. Litt. 289; 5 Coke, 4b; 11 Coke, 34b; 12 East, 372.
72i. Obedience is the essence of the law. 11 Coke, 100.
72h. Where there is no law, there is no transgression. 4 Coke, 16b.
72g. Law is a general rule of adherence to external acts. Black's, 700.
72f. Laws should bind their own maker. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 17, s. 11.
72e. Where there is no authority to establish, there is no necessity to obey. Day. 69; Bouv. 160.
72d. There is something more perfect in things allowed. Hob. 159.
72c. The law compels no one to do anything which is useless or impossible. C.L.M.; Hob. 96; Co. Litt. 231b; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 851. No one is bound to an impossibility. Jenk. Cent. 7.
72b. A law is not obligatory unless it be promulgated. Black's, 2d. 826; Bouv. 143.
72a. He does contrary to the law who does what the law prohibits; he acts in fraud of the law who, the letter of the law being inviolate, uses the law contrary to its intention. Dig. 1, 3, 29.
72. LAW (Adherence to) (See also: DUTY -:- JURISDICTION)
71ww. The law aids the vigilant, not the slothful or negligent. C.L.M. Smith v. Carll, 5 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 122, 145; Toole v. Cook, 16 How. Prac. (N.Y.) 142, 144; 1 Story, Cont. s. 529.
71vv. The reason of law changed, the law is also changed. 7 Coke, 7.
71uu. Reason is the soul of law; and when the reason of any law ceases, the law ceases also. Co. Litt. 70b, 122a; 2 Bl. Comm. 390, 391; Broom, Max. 159; C.L.M.; 4 Coke, 38.
71tt. The disposition of the law is more equitable than that of man. 8 Coke, 152,
71ss. The effect of the law consists in the execution. Co. Litt. 289b.
71rr. The law rejects superfluous, contradictory, and incongruous things. Jenk. Cent. 133.
71qq. Things which are found within the reason of a law are supposed to be within the law itself. 2 Inst. 689.
71pp. The law looks forward, not backward (i.e., is not ex post facto). Jenk. Cent. 284. The law provides for the future, the judge for the past. Bouv. 136.
71oo. Experience by various acts makes law. Experience is the mistress of things. Co. Litt. 60; Branch, Princ.
71nn. Law is the dictate of reason, which commands what is right, useful and necessary, and forbids the contrary. Co. Litt. 319b; Jenk. Cent. p. 117, case 33; 2 Inst. 587.
71mm. The law is the more praised when it is approved by reason. Broom, Max. 159.
71ll. Things which are inserted for the purpose of removing doubt hurt not the common law. Co. Litt. 205.
71kk. The law does not care for, or recognize, very small or trifling matters. Thus, error in calculation of a fractional part of a penny will not be regarded. Hob. 88; C.L.M.
71jj. The law always intends what is agreeable to reason. Co. Litt. 786.
71ii. The torture or wresting of laws is the worst kind of torture. 4 Bacon's Works, 434.
71hh. Extremities, or mere subtleties of law, are not rules of law, [are not law.] Co. Litt. 3046; 10 Coke, 126; Wing. Max. 19, max. 14; Broom, Max. 188.
71gg. All law has either been derived from the consent of the people, established by necessity, confirmed by custom, or of Divine Providence. Dig. 1, 3, 40; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 616, n.
71ff. The law dispenses what use has approved. C.L.M..
71ee. The laws themselves require that they should be governed by right. Co. Litt. 174.
71dd. These are the precepts of the law: To live honorably; to hurt nobody; to render to every one his due. Inst. 1, 1, 3; 1 BL Comm. 40.
71cc. Simplicity is favorable to the laws; and too much subtlety in law is to be reprobated. 4 Coke, 8.
71bb. The law will sooner suffer a mischief than an inconvenience. Litt. s. 231; Bouv. 135.
71aa. Law respects matter of substance more than matter of circumstance. Wing. Max. p. 382, max. 101; Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, no. 39.
71z. Law favors truth, faith, and certainty. Wing. Max. max. 154.
71y. Law favors speeding of men's causes. Wing. Max. max. 175.
71x. Law favors life, liberty, and dower. 4 Bacon's Works, 345.
71w. Law favors honor and order. Wing. Max. p. 739, max. 199.
71v. Law favors diligence, and therefore hates folly and negligence. Wing. Max. p. 665, max. 172; Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, no. 70.
71u. The law does nothing in vain. Jenk. Cent. p. 12, case 19; Broom, Max. 252.
71t. Law disfavors improbabilities or impossibilities. Wing. Max. p. 620, max. 161; p. 606, max. 155.
71s. Laws ought to be made with a view to those cases which happen most frequently, and not to those which are of rare or accidental occurrence. Dig. 1, 3, 3. Broom, Max. 43.
71r. An act of law shall prejudice no man. 2 Inst. 287; Hob. 216; 5 Term, 381, 385; Van Brunt v. Schenck, 11 Johns. (N.Y.) 380.
71q. The law arises out of the fact. Broom, Max. 102.
71p. Human laws are born, live, and die. 7 Coke, 25; 1 Bl. Comm. 89.
71o. The practice of fixing and refixing [making and remaking] the laws is a most dangerous one. 4 Coke, pref.
71n. Laws are imposed, not upon words, but upon things. 10 Coke, 101; Branch, Princ.; Code. 6, 43, 2.
71m. The law is the same respecting things which do not appear and those which do not exist. Bennehan v. Webb, 6 Ired. (N.C.) 57, 61; U.S. v. Wilkinson, 12 How. (53 U.S.) 246, 253; 5 Coke, 6.
71l. Law is made to prevent the stronger from having the power to do everything. Day. Ir. K.B. 36.
71k. The wisdom of the law cannot be valued by money. Jenk. Cent. 168.
71j. The welfare of the people is the supreme law. McInerney v. Ervin, (Fla.) 46 So.2d 458, 463; Bacon, Max. reg. 12; 13 Coke, 139.
71i. Law is established for the benefit of man. Black's, 2d. 577.
71h. Delays in law are odious. Branch, Princ. The law always abhors delays. 2 Inst. 240.
71g. Many things have been introduced into the common law, with a view to the public good, which are inconsistent with sound reason. Co. Litt. 70b; Broom, Max. 158; 2 Coke, 75.
71f. Law is a rule of right. Bouv. 136.
71e. Law is the science of what is good and just. Dig. 1, 1, 1, 1; Bract. fol. 2b.
71d. Law is from everlasting. Jenk. Cent. p. 34, case 66; Branch, Princ.
71c. Things favorably considered in law are life, liberty, dower, and treasury. Jenk. Cent. 94; Co. Litt. 341.
71b. A thing which has no effect in law is not an impediment. Jenk. Cent. Cas. 162; Wing. Max. 727.
71a. The laws consist not in being read, but in being understood. 8 Coke, 167a.
71. LAW, LAWS (See also: COMMON LAW -:- LAW OF NATURE -:- RULES)
70w. Land comprehends any ground, soil, or earth whatsoever; as mead ows, pastures, woods, moors, waters, and marshes. Co. Litt. 4a.
70v. Grain which is sown is understood to form a part of the soil. Inst. 2, 1, 32. What ever is planted in the soil belongs to the soil. 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1572.
70u. Gathered fruits do not make a part of the farm or realty. Dig. 19, 1, 17, 1; Bouv. Inst. no. 1578. 1 Tenement—Land, buildings, offices, franchises, etc., held by another by tenure. (66)
70t. Hanging fruits make part of the land. Dig. 6, 1, 44; 2 Bouv. Inst. no. 1578.
70s. Whichever of two parties has the division of an estate, the choice of the shares is the other's. Co. Litt. 166b.

70r. Whatever is affixed to or built on the soil belongs to the soil, whether attached by nature or by the hand of man. Broom, Max. 401-431; Inst. 2, 1, 29; Washburn v. Sproat, 16 Mass. 449; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1571; Dig. 41, 1, 7, 10; Nessler v. Neher, 26 N.W. 471; Co. Litt. 4a; Fleta, lib. 3, c. 2, s. 12.
70q. The law of God and the law of the land are all one; and both preserve and favor the private rights to the land. Keilw. 191.

70p. Allodial land is that possessed by a man in his own right, free and absolute, without owing any rent or service to any superior. Barker v. Dayton, 28 Wis. 367, 377; 2 Bl. Comm. 104; 3 Kent, Comm. 495.
70o. Buildings pass by a grant of the land. Fleta, lib. 3, c. 2, s. 12.
70n. The owner of a piece of land owns everything above and below it to an indefinite extent. Co. Litt. 4; 9 Coke, 54; Shep. Touch. 90; 2 Bl. Comm. 18; Broom, Max. 395; 2 Bout). Inst. nn. 15, 70.
70m. The situation and productiveness of the soil constitutes the value of the land. West River Bridge v. Dix, 6 Howard (47 U.S.) 507, 537.
70l. Water runs and ought to run as it has used to run. Bouv. 118; Kauffman v. Griesemer, 26 Penn. St. 407, 413; 3 Kent, Comm. 439.
70k. Water follows the land. A sale of land will pass the water which covers it. 2 Bl. Comm. 18; Co. Litt. 4.

70j. Every person has exclusive dominion over the soil which he absolutely owns; hence such an owner of land has the exclusive right of hunting and fishing on his land, and the waters covering it. L. Realty Co. v. Johnson, 92 Minn. 363, 365.
70i. In no tenements which is held for a term of years is there an avail of homage; but there is the oath of fealty (loyalty) Co. Litt. 67b.
70h. The shore is where the highest wave from the sea has reached. Dig. 50, 16, 96.
70g. An alien holds no lands. Tray. Lat. Max. 203.
70f. He who owns the soil has it even to the sky. C.L.M.; Co. Litt. 4a.
70e. Land lying unoccupied is given to the first occupant. C.L.M.
70d. A right descends, not the land. Co. Litt. 345.
70c. Every entry on lands without the owner's leave, or authority of law, is a trespass. C.L.M.
70b. What the original estate determines, the derivative estate determines also. 8 Coke, 34; Broom, Max. 495.
70a. An estate in free and pure allodium, and an estate in fee simple absolute, refer to essentilly the same thing. 4 Kent, Comm. 2.
70. LAND, REAL ESTATE (See also: HOMES -:- PROPERTY -:- INHERITANCE)
69y. Notice is named from a knowledge being had; and notice ought not to halt, [i.e., be imperfect.] 6 Coke, 29.
69x. It profits little to know what ought to be done, if you do not know how it is to be done. 2 Inst. 503.
69w. It is necessary that given persons, lands and estates should be comprehended in a declaration of uses. 9 Coke, 9.
69v. It is sometimes expedient to forget what you know. C.L.M.
69u. No man is bound to have foreknowledge of a Divine or a future event. 10 Coke, 55a.
69t. What is not read is not believed. 4 Coke, 304.
69s. Many men have known many things; no one has known everything. 4 Inst. 348.
69r. Not to believe rashly is the nerve of wisdom. 5 Coke, 114.
69q. No one is bound to give information about things he is ignorant of, but every one is bound to know that which he gives information about. Branch. Princ.; Black's, 2d. 815.
69p. Inquire into doubtful points if you wish to understand the law well [because by reasoning we arrive at legal reason] Litt. s. 337, 443;
69o. Let every one employ himself in what he knows. 11 Coke, 10.
69n. The law forces no one to make known what he is presumed not to know. Lofft, 569.
69m. To know the laws is not to observe their mere words, but their force and power; [that is, the essential meaning in which their efficacy resides.] Dig. 1, 3, 17; 1 Kent, Comm. 462.
69l. To know a thing, and to be bound to know it, are regarded in law as equivalent. Tray. Leg. Max. 551; Bouv. 129.
69k. Things universal are better known than things particular. 2 Rolle, 294.
69j. We are ignorant of many things which would not be hidden from us if the reading of old authors was familiar to us. 10 Coke, 73.
69i. To know properly is to know a thing in its reason, and by its cause. We are truly said to know anything, where we know the true cause thereof. Co. Litt. 183b.
69h. He who questions well learns well. 3 Bulst. 227.
69g. Jurisprudence is the knowledge of things Divine and human; the science of the just and the unjust. Dig. 1, 1, 10, 2; Inst. 1, 1, 1; Bract. 3; People v. Ruggles, 8 Johns. (N.Y.) 290, 295.
69f. The knowledge of smatterers is mixed ignorance. 8 Coke, 159.
69e. You will perceive many things much more easily by practice than by rules. 4 Inst. 50.
69d. No one can properly understand one part before he has read through the whole again and again. Broom, Max. 593; 3 Coke, 52.
69c. That which is necessarily understood is not wanting. 1 Bulst. 71. That which is tacitly understood is not considered to be wanting. 4 Coke, 22a.
69b. By reasoning we come to true reason. Litt. s. 386.
69a. Discretion is to know through law what is just. 10 Coke, 140.
69. KNOWLEDGE, UNDERSTANDING (See also: COMMON KNOWLEDGE -:- IGNORANCE)
68s. It is the property of a Judge to administer justice, not to give it. Lofft, 42.
68r. Justice is prior to liberty. Halk. Max. 77.
68q. Faith is the sister of justice. Halk. Max. 77.
68p. It is the duty of a good judge to enlarge or extend justice. 1 Burr. 304.
68o. Let right [or justice] be done, though the heavens should fall. Black's, 2d. 494.
68n. The law does not fail in dispensing justice. Jenk. Cent. p. 31, case 61; Co. Litt. 197.
68m. Justice knows not father nor mother; justice looks at truth alone. 1 Bulst. 199.
