68l. Justice is excellent virtue, and pleasing to the Most High. 4 Inst. 58.

68k. Favor ought not to be able to bend justice, power to break it, nor money to corrupt it; for not only if it be overborne, but if it be abandoned or negligently observed, no one can think that he holds any thing securely, or that he will inherit any thing from his father, or be able to leave any thing to his children. Bouv. 134; Cicero, Fragmenta de Republica.
68j. Justice is double; punishing severely, and truly preventing. 3 Inst. Epil.
68i. The law favors justice and right. Wing. Max. 141.
68h. That justice which absolutely prevents [a crime] is better than that which severely punishes it. 3 Inst. Epil.
68g. Justice is a steady and unceasing disposition to render to every man his due. Inst. 1, 1, pr.; Dig. 1, 1, 10.
68f. Justice is neither to be denied nor delayed. Jenk. Cent. 76, 93.
68e. Justice ought to be free, because nothing is more iniquitous than venal justice; full, because justice ought not to halt; and speedy, because delay is a kind of denial. 2 Inst. 56.
68d. Hasty justice is the step-mother of misfortune. Hob. 97.

68c. It is not just and right that he who exposes the faults of a guilty person should be condemned on that account; for it is proper and expedient that the offense of the guilty should be known. C.L.M.
68b. What is just and right is the law of laws. Hob. 224.
68a. Every presumption of the law must be in aid of justice. C.L.M.
68. JUSTICE (See also: EQUITY -:- LAW -:- TRUTH)
67h. The verdict of a jury is, as it were, the dictum of truth, even as the judgment of the court is the dictum of law. Co. Litt. 226.
67g. There can be no valid trial jury of less than 12 men, and a consent even by the defendant to a trial by a less number is absolutely void. Hunt v. State, 61 Miss. 577, 580, 581.
67f. The verdict of a jury is a bar to equity. Branch, Max. 155.
67e. The administration of an oath is an indispensable requisite to the formation of a legal jury. Lumsden v. City of Milwaukee, 8 Wis. 485, 486.
67d. A jury ought not to be harassed by labors and expenses. Jenk. Cent. 6.
67c. The decision of twelve good and upright men is thought by the common law to be the dictate of truth. Halk. Max. 73.
67b. Juries are the judges of fact and law in American jurisprudence. State of Georgia v. Brailsford, 3 Dall. 1, 4; U.S. v. Dougherty, 473 F.2d 1132-33.
67a. Jurors ought to be neighbors, of sufficient estate, and free from suspicion. Jenk. Cent. 141; Bouv. 134.
67. JURY, JURORS
66o. Jurisdiction is the power of a court to apply the law and to enter and enforce judgment. Jones v. Brinson, (N.C.) 78 S.E.2d 334, 337.
66n. Decisions are, as it were, jurisdictions. Halk. Max. 73.

66m. One who exercises jurisdiction out of his territory is not obeyed with impunity. Dig. 2, 1, 20; Branch, Princ.; 10 Coke, 77. He who exercises judicial authority beyond his proper limits cannot be obeyed with safety. Story, ConfL Laws, s. 539.
66l. One ought to be subject to the law [of the place] where he offends. 3 Inst. 24; Bract. fol. 154b.
66k. Whoever has an ordinary jurisdiction is ordinary of that place. Co. Litt. 344.
66j. The order of things is confounded if every one preserves not his jurisdiction. 4 Inst. Proem.
66i. He who has jurisdiction to loosen has jurisdiction to bind. 12 Coke, 59.
66h. The grant of jurisdiction implies the grant of all powers necessary to its exercise. 1 Kent, Comm. 339; Dig. 2, 1, 2;
66g. Every jurisdiction has its own bounds. Jenk. Cent. 137.

66f. Jurisdiction is the power to declare the law; and when it ceases to exist, the only function remaining to the court is that of announcing the fact and dismissing the cause. Bullington v. Angel, 220 N.C. 18
66e. Jurisdiction is a power introduced for the public good, on account of the necessity of dispensing justice. 10 Coke, 73a.
66d. Statutes are confined to their own territory, and have no extraterritorial effect. Woodworth v. Spring, 4 Allen (Mass.) 324.
66c. Jurisdiction of the principal matter extends to the accessory matter as well. 2 Inst. 493; Bract. 481.
66b. It is the part of a good judge to enlarge (or use liberally) his remedial authority or jurisdiction. Bouv. 119; Dwight v. Pomeroy, 17 Mass. 303, 310.
66a. A judicial act by a judge without jurisdiction is void; but a ministerial act, from whomsoever proceeding, may be ratified. Lofft. 458.
66. JURISDICTION (See also: AUTHORITY -:- JUDGE -:- JUDGMENT)
65bb. An alternative petition or demand is not to be heard. 5 Coke, 40.
65aa. It is unbecoming to surrender men when no cause is shown. In re Washburn, 4 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 106, 114, 8 Am. Dec. 548.
65z. An adjournment is to appoint a day or give a day. 4 Inst. 27.
65y. Everyone is presumed to be innocent until his guilt is established beyond a reasonable doubt. C.L.M. Every uncondemned person is held by the law as innocent. Lofft, 121.
65x. The judge is counsel for the prisoner. C.L.M.
65w. Judicial acts require the exercise of some judicial discretion, ministerial acts require none. Ex parte Kellogg, 6 Vt. 510.
65v. That which is endless is reprobated in law. 12 Coke, 24.
65u. Constitutions and laws precede the judiciary. Luther v. Borden, 7 How. (48 U.S.) 1, 52.

65t. Sunday is dies non juridicus —that is — it is not a court day, or a day for judicial proceedings, or legal purposes. Co. Litt. 135a; Noy, Max. 2; Wing. Max. 7, max. 5; Broom, Max. 21; Plowd. 265; Pearce v. Atwood, 13 Mass. 324, 327; VanVechten v. Paddock, 12 Johns. (N.Y.) 178, 180.
65s. No man should be condemned unheard. Broom, Max. 113.
65r. The condition of the defendant must be favored, rather than that of the plaintiff. Dig. 50, 17, 125; Broom, Max. 715.
65q. In a trial, credence is given only to those who are sworn. Cro. Car. 64.
65p. In courts or judicial proceedings, infancy is aided or favored. Jenk. Cent. 46, case 89.
65o. That which is to be resolved once for all should be long deliberated upon. 12 Coke, 74.
65n. Those things which are properly transacted in our courts ought to be committed to a due execution. Co. Litt. 289.
65m. An example [in judicial proceedings] does no good which settles one question by another. Hatch v. Mann, 15 Wend. (N.Y.) 44, 49.
65l. An act of the court shall prejudice no man. Jenk. Cent. 118; 1 Smith, Lead. Cas. 245-255; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 115.
65k. The great number of ignorant and unskillful practitioners destroys a court. 2 Inst. 219.
65j. The practice of the court is the law of the court. 3 Bulst. 53.
65i. Summonses or citations should not be granted before it is expressed on what ground they ought to be issued. 12 Coke, 47.
65h. No court which has not a record can impose a fine, or commit any person to prison; because those powers belong only to courts of record. 8 Coke, 60.
65g. A judicial writ fails not through defect of form. Jenk. Cent. 43
65f. The court has nothing to do with what is not before it. Bacon, Max; Bouv. 141.
65e. It is the duty of a good judge to prevent litigations, that suit may not grow out of suit, and it concerns the welfare of a state that an end be put to litigation. 4 Coke, 15b; 5 Coke, 31a.
65d. No one who may condemn is unable to acquit. Dig. 50, 17, 37.
65c. An action of a judge which relates not to his office is of no force. Dig. 50, 17, 170; 10 Coke, 76. A judicial act before one not a judge is void. Lofft. 458.
65b. The decree (or act) of a court shall prejudice no man. Jenk. Cent. 118; C.L.M.
65a. It matters not what is known to the judge, if it is not known to him judicially. 3 Bulstr. 115; Best, Ev. Introd. 31, s. 38.
65. JUDICIAL ACTS & PROCEDURES (See also: JUDGES -:- LEGAL ACTION -:- SUITS)
64kk. In nearly all penal judgments, immaturity of age and imbecility of mind are favored. Dig. 50, 17, 108; Broom, Max. 314.
64jj. `The same reason, the same law.' Charles River Bridge v. Warren Bridge, 7 Pick. (Mass.) 493,
64ii. The law does not define exactly, but trusts in the judgment of a good man. Bissell v. Briggs, 9 Mass. 475, 6 Am. Dec. 88.
64hh. Of [respecting] like things, [in like cases,] the judgment is to be the same. 7 Coke, 18.
64gg. Every conclusion of a good and true judgment follows from good and true premises, and the verdicts of jurors. Co. Litt. 226b.
64ff. A court can only declare what the law is, and whether consistent with the law of God, and the fundamental or constitutional law of society. The State v. Post, 20 N.J.L. 368, 370 (1845).
64ee. Judgments frequently become matured by deliberations, never by hurried process or precipitation. 3 Inst. 210.

64dd. It is improper to give judgment or pass sentence without looking at the whole case. Dig. 1, 3, 24; Hob. 171a. It is unjust to decide or respond as to any particular part of a law without examining the whole of the law. 8 Coke, 117b.
64cc. In things preceding judgment the plaintiff is favored. 2 Inst. 57
64bb. He who determines any matter without hearing both sides, though he may have decided right, has not done justice. 6 Coke, 52a; 4 Bl. Comm. 283.
64aa. Judgment is, as it were, a declaration of law. Black's, 670.
64z. A thing adjudged makes white, black; black, white; the crooked, straight; the straight, crooked. 1 Bouv. Inst. no. 840.
64y. A matter decided or passed upon by a court of competent jurisdiction is received as evidence of truth. 2 Kent, Comm. 120. Dig. 50, 17, 207.
64x. Matters adjudged in a cause do not prejudice those who were not parties to it. Dig. 44, 2, 1.
64w. The law judges those things which must necessarily be done as if actually done. Branch. Princ.

64v. A new adjudication does not make a new law, but declares the old; because adjudication is the utterance of the law, and by adjudication the law is newly revealed which was for a long time hidden. 10 Coke, 42.
64u. Every act is to be judged by the intention of the doer. Branch, Princ.
64t. That which appears not is not; and nothing appears judicially before judgment. 2 Inst. 479.
64s. One of two opposite positions being affirmed, the other is denied. 3 Rolle, 422.
64r. Judgment in error is a judgment rendered by a court of error on a record sent up from an inferior court. Black's, 666.
64q. Realities must dominate the judgment by a court. Appalachian Coals v. United States, 288 U.S. 344, 360.
64p. The intention, count, foundation, and thing, brought to judgment, ought to be certain. Co. Litt. 303a; Jenk. Cent. 84.

64o. It is always safer to err in acquitting than punishing; or deciding on the side of mercy than on the side of justice. Branch, Princ.; 2 Hale, P.C. 290; Broom, Max. 326; Corn. v. York, 9 Metc. (Mass.) 116, 43 Am. Dec. 373.
64n. The verdict is, as it were, the dictum of truth; as the judgment is the dictum of law. Co. Litt. 226.
64m. He who flees judgment confesses his guilt. 3 Inst. 14.
64l. A judgment ought not to be illusory, it ought to have its proper effect. 2 Inst. 341.
64k. Sentence is not given upon matters that are not clear. Jenk. Cent. p. 7, case 9.
64j. An interlocutory judgment may be recalled, but not a final one. Bacon, Max. reg. 20.
64i. Judgment must be by the laws, not by examples. C.L.M.; 4 Coke, 33b; 4 Bl. Comm. 405; Skinner v. Dayton, 19 Johns. (N.Y.) 513.
64h. Nothing in law is more intolerable than that the same case or matter should be subject (in different courts) to different views of the law. 4 Coke, 93.
64g. Where the opinions are equal, [where the court is equallydivided,] the defendant is acquitted. 4 Inst. 64. (5 8)
64f. The judge in his decision ought to follow the rule, when the exception is not proved. Black's, 2d. 669; Bouv. 133.
64e. Judgments are, as it were, the dicta or sayings of the law, and are received as truth. 2 Inst. 537; Co. Litt. 39a, 168a.
64d. In presumption of law, a judgment is given against inclination. Co. Litt. 248b, 314b.
64c. An award is a judgment. Jenk. Cent. 137; 3 Bulst. 64.
64b. A compromise is brought into affinity with judgments. Strong v. Strong, 9 Cush. (Mass.) 571.
64a. A judgment given by one who is not the proper judge is of no force and should not harm any one. 10 Coke, 70, 766; Bouv. 133; Fleta, 1. 6, c. 6, s. 7; Broom, Max. 92.
64. JUDGMENT & DECISION (See also: JUDGE -:- JUDICIAL ACTS)
63bb. It is the duty of a judge to inquire into the times of things, as well as into things themselves. Co. Litt. 171a.
63aa. Judges are not bound to explain the reason of their sentence. Jenk. Cent. 75.
63z. A judge who exceeds his office or jurisdiction is not to be obeyed. Jenk. Cent. p. 139, case 84; Bouv. 133.
63y. It is the duty of a judge to declare [enunciate] the law, not to enact the law or make it. Lofft, 42; Tray. Leg. Max. 283; Lofft. App. 42.
63x. Judges are by no means favorable to things raised recently and subtly against the common law. Halk. Max. 73.
63w. It is the duty of a judge to decide according to the facts alleged and proved. Dyer, 12; Halk. Max. 73.
63v. It is punishment enough for a judge that he has God as his avenger [i.e., he is responsible to God]. Bouv. 133.
63u. A judge cannot punish a wrong done to himself. 12 Coke, 114; Bouv. 133.
63t. A judge should have two salts: the salt of wisdom, lest he be insipid; and the salt of conscience, lest he be devilish. Black's, 2d. 664; 3 Inst. 147.
63s. A judge ought always to have equity before his eyes. Jenk. Cent. 45, 58; Halk. Max. 71.
63r. A judge should keep his jurisdiction within the limits of his commission. 4 Inst. 163; Black's, 2d. 1056.
63q. That law is best which leaves least to the discretion of the judge; that judge is best who leaves least to his own opinion. Broom, Max. 84; 1 Kent, Comm. 478; Bacon, Aph. 8, 46.
63p. The ignorance of the judge is the misfortune of the innocent. 2 Inst. 591.
63o. A Judge is the law speaking, [the mouth of the law.] 7 Coke, 4a.

63n. The judge must see that no order be made or judgment given or sentence passed either more harshly or more mildly than the case requires; he must not seek renown, either as a severe or as a tender-hearted judge. Black's, 1028.
63m. Whatever is subject to the authority of a judge is not subject to innovation. 4 Inst. 66.
63l. It is the duty of a good judge to cause judgment to be executed without delay. Co. Litt. 289.
63k. It is the duty of a good judge to remove causes of litigation. 2 Inst. 306.
63j. It is the duty of justices to administer justice to every one pleading before them. 2 Inst. 451.
63i. The law provides for the future, the judge for the past. Black's, 717.
63h. If you judge, understand. Bouv. 157.
63g. The judge is condemned when a guilty person escapes punishment. Black's, 664: Bouv. 133.
63f. A good judge should do nothing of his own arbitrary will, nor on the dictate of his personal inclination, but should decide according to law and justice. 7 Coke, 27a.
63e. The practice of the judges is the interpreter of the laws. Hob. 96.
63d. No one can be a judge in his own cause. Branch, Princ.; 12 Coke, 13. A judge cannot be a witness in his own case. 4 Inst. 272.
63c. A good judge decides according to what is just and right, and prefers equity to strict law. Co. Litt. 24; Jenk. Cent. p. 45, case 85; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 77; 4 Term 344.
63b. A judge's order is an order made by a judge at chambers, or out of court. Black's, 664.

63a. Concerning the fidelity and official conduct of a judge, no question is [will be] entertained; but his decisions may be impugned for the error committed of law or fact. Bacon, Max. 68, reg. 17; 1 N.Y. 45; Broom, Max. 85.
63. JUDGE, JUDGES (See also: JUDGMENT -:- JUDICIAL ACTS)

62p. An unconstitutional Act is not a law; it confers no rights; it imposes no duties; it affords no protection; it creates no office; it is, in legal contemplation, as inoperative as though it had never been passed. Norton v. Shelby County, 118 U.S. 425, 442.
62o. Things grounded upon an ill and void beginning cannot have a valid or good perfection. Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, n. 8.
62n. He who concedes anything is considered as conceding that without which his concession would be void; or without which the thing itself could not exist. 11 Coke, 52.
62m. Void in part, void in toto. C.L.M.
62l. Time cannot render valid an act void in its origin. Dig. 50, 17, 29.
62k. Things shall not be void which may possibly be good. Bouv. 160.
62j. Voidable imports a valid act which may be avoided, rather than an invalid act which may be confirmed as such. Rothberg v. Schmiedeskamp, 134 N.E.2d 544, 546, 334 Mass. 172.
62i. A thing void ab initio is one that never went into effect. C.L.M.
62h. What is useful is not vitiated by the useless. 3 Bouv. Inst. n. 2949; Iredell v. Barbee, 9 Ired. (N.C.) 254; 2 Serg. & R. (Penn.) 298.
62g. That which is valid in law has legal strength, force, and effect, or incapable of being rightfully overthrown or set aside. Emerson v. Knapp, 75 Mo.App. 92, 97.
62f. The mandate of an immoral or illegal thing is void. Dig. 17, 1, 6, 3.
62e. What ought not to be done, when done, is valid. 5 Coke, 38, 39; Nichols v. Ketchan, 19 Johns. (N.Y.) 84, 92.
62d. Void things are as no things. People v. Shall, 9 Cow. (N.Y.) 784.
62c. Things invalid from the beginning cannot be made valid by subsequent act. Tray. Leg. Max. 482.
62b. A repugnant act cannot be brought into being, i.e., cannot be made effectual. Plowd. 355.
62a. A conclusion as to the use of a thing from its abuse is invalid. Broom, Max. 17.
62. INVALID, VALID, VOID (See also: ANNUL -:- LAWFUL)
61s. A burdensome condition ought not to be brought upon one man by the act of another. Dig. 50, 17, 74; 2 Kent, Comm. 646.
61r. Whose is the advantage, his also should be the disadvantage. Black's, 2d. 304.
61q. Personal things die with the person. Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, n. 16.
61p. Personal things follow the person. Flanders v. Cross, 10 Cush. (Mass.) 516.
61o. Personal things cannot be done by another. Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, n. 14.
61n. A personal connection is equivalent to one's own interest; nearness of blood is as good a consideration as one's own interest. Bacon, Max. 72, reg.
61m. No man can forfeit another's right. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 28, s. 11.
61l. A person ought not to be prejudiced by what has been done between others. C.L.M.
61k. He who condemns the precept condemns the party giving it. 12 Coke, 96.
61j. Transactions between strangers may benefit, but cannot injure those who are not parties to them. 6 Coke, 1; Co. Litt. 132; Broom, Max. 954, 967.
61i. You ought to know with whom you deal. C.L.M.
61h. The law favors mutual recompense. Wing. Max. 100.
61g. Impersonality neither concludes nor binds. Co. Litt. 352.
61f. When suspicion between men is suggested, it is easily entertained. C.L.M.
61e. No one can transfer more [or greater] right to another than he has himself. Dig. 50, 17, 54; Broom, Max. 467, 469; ling. Max. 56.
61d. No one should intermeddle with a thing that in no respect concerns him. Jenk. Cent. p. 18, case 32.
61c. He who first offends causes the strife. Bouv. 152.
61b. It is difficult that one man should sustain the place of two. 4 Coke, 118.
61a. No one ought to be enriched by another's loss. Dig. 6, 1, 48, 65; 2 Kent, Comm. 336; 1 Kames, Eq. 331; Jenk. Cent. 4; Taylor v. Baldwin, 10 Barb. (N.Y.) 626, 633.
61. INTERPERSONAL RELATIONSHIP (See also: HUMAN NATURE -:- SUITS)
60o. A reason cannot always be given for the intentions of our ancestors. 4 Coke, 79; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 149; Branch, Princ.

60n. An act does not make [the doer of it] guilty, unless the mind be guilty; that is, unless the intention be criminal. 3 Inst. 107. The intent and the act must both concur to constitute the crime. 7 Term 514; Broom, Max. 306; Howard v. Sexton, 4 N.Y. 157, 159.
60m. Without the knowledge, the intent cannot exist. Direct Sales Co. v. United States, 319 U.S. 703, 711.
60l. Intentions ought to be subservient to [or in accordance with] the laws, not the laws to intentions. Co. Litt. 314a, 314b.
60k. Previous intentions are judged by subsequent acts. Dumont v. Smith, 4 Denio (N.Y.) 319, 320.
60j. A hidden intention is bad and disfavored in law. 2 Bulstr. 179.
60i. Your intention (or disposition) gives name (or character) to your work or act. Bract. fol. 2b, 101b; Hob. 123.
60h. An action does not make one guilty, unless the intention be bad. Lofft. 37.
60g. Language is the exponent of the intention. The language of a statute or instrument is the best guide to the intention. Broom, Max. 622.
60f. Outward acts indicate the inward intent. Broom, Max. 3. 270; 1 Smith, Lead. Cas. 115; 8 Coke, 291.
60e. It is to the intention that all law applies. Law always regards the intention. Black's, 2d, 70; Bouv. 118.
60d. Words should be subordinate to the intention. C.L.M.
60c. The intention amounts to nothing unless some effect follows. 1 Rolle, 226; Bouv. 143.
60b. That which is first in intention is last in operation. Bacon, Max.
60a. The intention of the party is the soul of the instrument. 3 Bulst. 67.
60. INTENT, INTENTION (See also: CONSTRUCTION -:- WORDS)
59y. Bodily injuries cannot be foreseen and guarded against by means of provisos. Bacon, Max. reg. 22.
59x. Extreme caution does no harm. 11 Coke, 6b; Fleta, lib. 1, c. 28, s.1.
59w. An action is not given to one who is not injured. Jenk. Cent. 69.
59v. From things to which one is accustomed, or in which there has been long acquiescence, no injury or wrong arises. Jenk. Cent. Intro. viii.
59u. No one should be injured by that which has taken place between other parties. Dig. 12, 2, 10.
59t. What constitutes right, and what injury, it is the business of the law to declare. Co. Litt. 158b.
59s. Damage derived by consent is not a cause of action. Wing. Max. 482. An injury is not done to one who knows and wills it. Bract. fol. 20.

59r. Use your own property in such a manner so as not to injure that of another. 9 Coke, 59; 1 Bl. Comm. 306; Broom, Max. 365; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 2379; Marcy v. Clark, 17 Mass. 334; McInerney v. Ervin, (Fla.) 46 So.2d 458, 463.
59q. The act of the law does injury to no one. 2 Inst. 287; 5 Coke, 116.
59p. It is for the interest of the state that a man should not enjoy his own property improperly, to the injury of others. Inst. 1, 8, 2.
59o. Law is a rule of right; and whatever is contrary to the rule of right is an injury. 3 Bulst. 313.
59n. According to the laws of nature, it is just that no one should be enriched through detriment and injury to another, i.e., at another's expense. Dig. 50, 17, 200.
59m. An injury is extinguished by the forgiveness or reconcilement of the party injured. Ersk. Inst. 4, 4, 108.
59l. An injury is done to him of whom a reproachful thing is said, or concerning whom an infamous song is made. 9 Coke, 60.
59k. He who suffers a damage by his own fault is not held to suffer damage. Dig. 50, 17, 203.
59j. No one is considered as doing damage, unless he is doing what he has no right to do. Dig. 50, 17, 151.
59i. No man can change his purpose to another's injury. Dig. 50, 17, 75; Broom, Max. 34.
59h. A personal injury does not receive satisfaction from a future course of proceeding, [is not left for its satisfaction to a future course of proceeding.] Bacon, Max. reg. 6; Broom, Max. 278.
59g. The government cannot confer a favor which occasions injury and loss to others. 3 Coke, 236; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 60.
59f. He who does not repel an injury when he can, induces it. Jenk. Cent. 271.
59e. Extreme law (rigor of law) is the greatest injury; strict law is great punishment. Hob. 125.
59d. The Act of God injures no one. 2 Inst. 287; C.L.M.; 2 Bl. Comm. 122; 1 Coke, 97b; Co. Litt. 206a.
59c. Injury is not presumed. Co. Litt. 232.
59b. Not every loss produces an injury, i.e., gives a right of action. 3 Bl. Comm. 219; 1 Smith, Lead. Cas. 131; Broom, Max. 93; 2 Bouv., Inst. n. 2211.
59a. There may be damage or injury inflicted without any act of injustice. Lofft, 112.
59. INJURY, DAMAGE, HARM (See also: FAULT -:- REMEDY)
58mm. No one is presumed to have preferred another's posterity to his own. Wing. Max. 285.

58ll. No one is heir to the living. Co. Litt. 8a, 22b; 2 BL Comm. 70; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1694; Jackson v. Kniffen, 2 Johns. (N.Y.) 36. No one can be heir during the life of his ancestor. Broom, Max. 522.
58kk. The greater inheritance comes to every one of us from right and the laws than from parents. 2 Inst. 56.
58jj. A son in the mother's womb is part of the mother's vitals. 7 Coke, 8.
58ii. "Heir" is a name or term of law; "son" is a name of nature. Bacon, Max. 52, in reg. 11.
58hh. A yearly increase goes to enhance the inheritance. Dig. 5, 3, 20, 3.
58gg. He who is born outside of lawful matrimony, or of an unlawful one, follows the condition of the mother. C.L.M.; CycL Dict. 840.
58ff. The offspring of an illicit cohabitation are not reckoned among the children. C.L.M; Co. Litt. 8a; Broom, Max. 519.
58ee. An heir is a part of his ancestor. Co. Litt. 22; Branch, Princ; Schoonmaker v. Sheely, 3 Hill. (N.Y.) 165, 167.
58dd. An heir is either by right of property, or right of representation. 3 Coke, 40b.
58cc. Possession of the brother in fee-simple makes the sister to be heir. 3 Coke, 42; 2 Bl. Comm. 227.
58bb. The presumption is in favor of legitimacy. 1 Bl. Comm. 457; 5 Coke, 98b; Co. Litt. 126a.
58aa. All sisters are, as it were, one heir to the inheritance. Co. Litt. 67.
58z. He who would have been heir to the father of the deceased shall also be heir of the son. 2 Bl. Comm. 239, 250; Broom, Max. 517.
58y. The heir succeeds to the restitution, not the penalty. 2 Inst. 198.
58x. An heir minor, under twenty-one years of age, is not answerable, except in the matter of dower. Moore, 348.
58w. He is the lawful heir whom the marriage demonstrates. Fleta, 1, 6, c. 1; Dig. 2, 4, 5; Co. Litt. 7b.
58v. The heir is not to be bound in a penalty arising out of the wrongful act of the ancestor. 2 Inst. 198.
58u. He who provides for himself provides for his heirs. Black's, 2d. 980.

58t. A penal action is not given against an heir, unless such heir is benefited by the wrong. Black's, 2d. 25. Penal actions arising from any thing of a criminal nature do not pass to heirs. 2 Inst. 442.
58s. Children are of the blood of their parents, but the father and mother are not of the blood of the children. 3 Coke, 40.
58r. The right of survivorship, for the benefit of commerce, holds no place among merchants. C.L.M.
58q. No one can at the same time be the heir and the owner of the same tenement. Hale, Com. Law, c. 7; Bouv. 141.
58p. One may relinquish for himself and his heirs a right which was introduced for his own benefit. Bract. 20.
58o. God alone makes the heir, not man. Co. Litt. 5, 7b; Broom, Max. 516.
58n. No one leaves a greater benefit to his heir than he had himself. Dig. 50, 17, 120.
58m. An inheritance is either corporeal or incorporeal. Corporeal is that which can be touched and seen; incorporeal, that which can neither be touched nor seen. Co. Litt. 9.
58l. A right growing to a possessor accrues to a successor. Halk. Max. 76.
58k. Co-heirs are deemed as one body or person, by reason of the unity of right which they possess. Co. Litt. 163.
58j. By the title of heirs, come the heirs of heirs to infinity. Co. Litt. 9.

58i. Children born under a legitimate marriage shall always follow the condition of the father, never that of the mother. Co. Litt. 123; Black's, 2d. 305; Lynch v. Clarke, 1 Sandf. Ch. (N.Y.) 583, 660. However, in the case of slaves and animals, the offspring follows the condition of the mother. Inst. 2, 1, 9; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 167, 502.
58h. The law favors the inheritance of a man. C.L.M.
58g. Fee-tail, — an inheritance limited in a definite descent. Litt. s. 13; Black's, 2d. 491.

58f. A fee-simple, so called because fee is the same as inheritance, and simple is the same as lawful or pure; and thus fee-simple is the same as a lawful inheritance, or pure inheritance. Litt. s. 1; Black's, 2d. 490.
58e. Not to be born, and to be dead-born, are the same thing. C.L.M.
58d. Not right, but seisin (legal possession), makes a stock from which the inheritance must descend. Fleta, 1.6, cc. 14, 2, s. 2; Noy, Max. 9th ed. 72, n. (b); Broom, Max. 466; 2 BL Comm. 388, 389.
58c. He who is in the womb is considered as born, whenever his benefit is concerned. Bouv. 151; Black's, 979.
58b. Inheritance is the succession to every right which the deceased had. Co. Litt. 237; Dig. 50, 17, 62.
58a. It is not just to make an elder born a bastard after his death, who during his lifetime was accounted legitimate. 12 Coke, 44.
58. INHERITANCE, HEIR, & DESCENT (See also: PROPERTY RIGHTS -:- MARRIAGE -:- WILLS)
57j. Ignorance of one's right does not prejudice the right. Lofft. 552.

57i. Ignorance, or want of skill, is considered a fault, i.e., a negligence, for which one who professes the skill is responsible. Dig. 50, 17, 132; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 1004; 2 Kent, Comm. 588; McDonald v. Simpson, 4 Ark. 523.
57h. The law assists the ignorant. Jenk. Cent. 15.

57g. A mistake in point of law is, in criminal cases, no sort of defense. 4 Bl. Comm. 27; 4 Steph. Comm. 81; Broom, Max. 253; 7 Car. P. 456. And, in civil cases, ignorance of the law, with a full knowledge of the facts, furnishes no ground, either in law or equity, to rescind agreements, or reclaim money paid, or set aside solemn acts of the parties. 2 Kent, Comm. 491, and note.

57f. Ignorance of the fact excuses; ignorance of the law excuses not. Every man must be taken to be cognizant of the law; otherwise there is no saying to what extent the excuse of ignorance may not be carried. 1 Coke, 177; Broom, Max. 253; 4 Bouv. Inst. n. 3828.
57e. It is ignorance of the law when we do not know our own rights. Haven v. Foster, 9 Pick. (Mass.) 130, 19 Am. Dec. 353.

57d. Ignorance of fact excuses or is ground of relief. 2 Coke, 3b. Acts done and contracts made under mistake or ignorance of a material fact are voidable and relievable in law and equity. 2 Kent, Comm. 491, & notes.
57c. Ignorance of law excuses no one (for all are bound to know the law). 4 Bouv. Inst. no. 3828; 1 Story, Eq. Jur. s. 111; 2 Coke, 36; Rankin v. Mortimere, 7 Watts (Penn.) 374; 2 Kent, Comm. 491.
57b. It is a rule, that every one is prejudiced by his ignorance of law, but not by his ignorance of fact. Code. 1, 18, 10.
57a. Ignorance of those things which one is bound to know excuses not. Hale, P.C. 42; Broom, Max. 267; 4 Bl. Comm. 27.
57. IGNORANCE (See also: KNOWLEDGE -:- ERROR)
56d. Identity ordinarily connotes exactness. Gordon v. Gordon, 59 So.2d 40, 44.
56c. Identity of a thing means the sameness in all that constitutes the objective reality of a thing. State v. Evjue, 33 N.W.2d 305, 309.
56b. He who cannot be known from himself, may be known from his associate. Moore, 817.
56a. From a great number of signs or marks, true identity is ascertained Bacon, Max. 103, in reg. 25, 29; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 569.
56. IDENTITY, IDENTIFY
55g. To cover reproach with reproach is to lay mud upon mud. Bulst. 86.
55f. He acts with guile who demands that which he will have to return. Broom, Max. 346.
55e. If you be moved to anger by insults, you publish them; if despised, they are forgotten. 3 Inst. 198.
55d. Anger is a short insanity. Beardsley v. Maynard, 4 Wend. (N.Y.) 336, 355.
55c. He is insane who, reason being thrown away, does everything with violence and rage. 4 Coke, 128.
55b. To him to whom nothing is enough, nothing is base. 4 Inst. 53.
55a. Human nature does not change with time or environment. C.L.M.
55. HUMAN NATURE & FAULTS
54h. A home is a social unit formed by a family living together in one dwelling. Anaya v. Foundation Res. Ins. Co., 414 P.2d 848, 849.

54g. A man's dwelling-house is his castle and fortress, not merely for his own personal protection, but also for the protection of his family and his property therein. 5 Coke, 91b; Broom, Max. 432; Curtis v. Hubbard, 4 Hill (N.Y.) 437.
54f. Every man's house should be a perfectly safe refuge. 3 Inst. 162. Clason v. Shotwell, 12 Johns. (N.Y.) 31, 54; 5 Coke, 91b; 11 Id. 82
54e. A citizen cannot be taken by force from his house to be conducted before a judge or to prison. Dig. 50, 17, 103.
54d. Every man's house is his castle; and even though the winds of heaven may blow through it, government officials cannot enter it. C.L.M.; 5 Coke, 91, 92.
54c. There is nothing more sacred, more inviolate, than the house of every citizen. C.L.M.

54b. It is settled that that is to be considered the home of each one of us where he may have his habitation and account-books, and where he has made an establishment of his business. Dig. 50, 16, 203.
54a. Residence creates domicile. Arnold v. United Ins. Co., 1 Johns. Cas. (N.Y.) 363, 366.

53d. That guardianship is secure which is intrusted to itself alone. Hob. 340.
53c. If a guardian do fraud to his ward, he shall be removed from his guardianship. Jenk. Cent. 39.
53b. A guardian ought not to make money out of the guardianship of his ward. Manning v. Manning's Ex 'rs, 1 Johns. Ch. (N. Y.) 527, 535.
53a. A guardian can make the estate of an existing heir under his guardianship better, not worse. 7 Coke, 7.

52l. If a man grant that which is not his, the grant is void. Shep. Touch. 243; Watk. Cony. 191.
52k. To permit is to allow by passive consent or not hindering; or to grant leave to by express consent or authorization. Hill v. Montgomery, 176 S.W.2d 284, 287, 352 Mo. 147.
52j. That which is permitted only at a loss is not permitted to be done. Co. Litt. 127.

52h. He who gives an end gives the means to that end. 3 Mass. 129.
52g. The right of the grantor being extinguished, the right granted is extinguished. Broom, Max. 467.
52f. He who is permitted to do the greater may with greater reason do the less. Dig. 50, 17, 21; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 165; Shep. Touch. 429.
52e. It is not every thing which is permitted that is honorable. Dig. 50, 17, 144.
52d. Permission is a license to do a thing or an authority to do an act, without such authority, would have been unlawful. Black's, 893.

51r. As usurpation is the exercise of power, which another has a right to; so tyranny is the exercise of power beyond right, which no body can have a right to. Locke, Treat. 2, 18, 199.
51p. The main object of government is the protection and preservation of personal rights, private property, and public liberties, and upholding the law of God. American Maxim.
51o. All political power is inherent in the people by decree of God, thus none can exist except it be derived from them. American Maxim.

51k. The law is not to be violated by those in government. Jenk. Cent. 7.
51j. Were the executive power not to have a right of restraining the encroachments of the legislative body, the latter would become despotic. Montesquieu, The Spirit of Laws.
51i. Individual liberties are antecedent to all government. C.L.M.
51h. The minister of the law is not bound, in the execution of his office, either to fly or retreat. 6 Coke, 68.
51g. The absence of him who is employed in the service of the state, should not be prejudicial to him nor to others. Dig. 50, 17, 140.
51f. An ambassador fills the place of the king or nation by whom he is sent, and is to be honored as he whose place he fills. 12 Coke, 17.
51e. No one should hold two offices at the same time. 4 Inst. 100. (46)
51d. The laws themselves desire that they should be governed by right. Co. Litt. 174b.
51c. Obedience makes government, not the name by which it is called. C.L.M.
51b. The government is to be subject to the law, for the law makes the government. C.L.M.
51a. The government cannot load a citizen with imposition against his will or consent. 2 Coke, 61.

50f. A possessor in good faith is only liable for that which he himself has obtained. 2 Inst. 285.
50e. Good faith does not allow us to demand twice the payment of the same thing. Dig. 50, 17, 57; Perline v. Dunn, 4 Johns Ch. (NY) 143.
50d. Good faith must be observed. Coolidge v. Brigham, 1 Metc. (Mass.) 547, 551.
50c. Good faith demands that what is agreed upon shall be done. Dig. 19, 20, 21; Id. 19, 1, 50; Id. 50, 8, 2, 13.
50b. By good faith a possessor makes the fruits consumed his own. Tray. Max. 57.
50a. Good faith does not suffer the same thing to be demanded twice; and in making satisfaction [for a debt or demand] it is not allowed to be done more than once. 9 Coke, 53; Dig. 50, 17, 57.
50. GOOD FAITH
49l. That which is against Divine Law is repugnant to society and is void. C.L.M.
49k. What is given to the church is given to God. 2 Inst. 590.
49j. No man warring for God should be troubled by secular business. Co. Litt. 70.
49i. The Christian religion is a part of the common law. Lofft. 327.
49h. No one was ever a great man without some Divine inspiration. Cicero; Bouv. 141.
49g. That consideration is strongest which determines in favor of religion. Co. Litt. 341a; 5 Coke, 14b; Dig. 11, 7, 43.
49f. That is the highest law which favors religion. 10 Mod. 117, 119; Broom, Max. 19.
49e. It is more serious to hurt Divine than temporal majesty. 11 Coke, 29.
49d. Reason is a ray of the Divine light. Co. Litt. 232.
49c. No one is obliged to accuse himself, unless before God. Hardr. 139.
49b. Human things never prosper where Divine things are neglected. Co. Litt. 15; Wing. Max. 2.
49a. Where the Divinity is insulted the case is unpardonable. Jenk. Cent. 167.

48v. It is necessary that a certain thing be brought into the gift, or made the subject of the conveyance. Bract. fol. 15b.
48u. The donor never ceases to possess, until the donee begins to possess. Bract. fol. 41b; Dyer, 281.
48t. He who has a right to give has the right to dispose of the gift. Wing. Max. 53; 2 Coke, 71; Broom, Max. 459, 461.

48s. A gift is perfected [made complete] by the possession of the receiver. Jenk. Cent. 109, case 9. A gift is incomplete until possession is delivered. 2 Kent, Comm. 438; Ewing v. Ewing, 2 Leigh. (Va.) 337
48r. Among other methods of acquiring property, a great, much-used, and celebrated method is that of gift. Bract. fol. 11.
48q. A gift is not presumed. Jenk. Cent. 109. No one is presumed to give. Haren v. Foster, 9 Pick. (Mass.) 128, 19 Am. Dec. 353.
48p. To present is no more than to give or offer on the spot. Co. Litt. 120.
48o. One who knowingly pays what is not due is supposed to have done it with the intention of making a gift. Walker v. Hill, 17 Mass. 388.
48n. That which one has given, knowing it not to be due, with the intention of redemanding it, he cannot recover back. Dig. 12, 6, 50.
48m. He gives nothing who has nothing. Cycl. Dict. 693.
48l. A thing is said to be given when it is yielded otherwise than by virtue of right (i.e., when the receiving party has no right to the thing). Dig. 50, 17, 82.
48k. Custom gives law to the gift. Co Litt. 19; Broom, Max. 459.
48j. Whatever is received is received according to the intention of the recipient. Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 727; Halk. Max. 149.
48i. A gift is said to be pure and simple when no condition or qualification is annexed. Bract. 1; Bouv. 158.
48h. The will of the donor manifestly expressed in his deed of giving a gift is to be observed. Co. Litt. 21.
48g. A bequest is not rendered void by an erroneous description. Inst. 2, 20, 30; Broom, Max. 645.
48f. The manner gives law to a gift. Co. Litt. 19a.
48e. That is considered to be given which is granted when no law compels. Dig. 50, 17, 82.
48d. No man can give that which he has not. Fleta, lib. 3, c. 15, s. 8; Jenk. Cent. 250; Broom, Max. 499n; Jackson v. Bradford, 4 Wend. (N.Y.) 619; Shep. Touch. 243;
48c. Clandestine gifts are always suspicious. 3 Coke, 81; Noy, Max. 152.
48b. One who gives and yet retains does not give effectually. Or, one who gives, yet retains, gives nothing. Tray. Leg. Max. 129.
48a. He who gives a thing by mistake has a right to recover it back; but, if he gives designedly (with knowledge of the facts), it is a gift. Dig. 50, 17, 53.

47i. It is a wretched state of slavery which subsists where the law is vague or uncertain. 4 Inst. 245, 246; Broom, Max. 150; Yates v. Lansing, 9 Johns. (N.Y.) 427.
47h. Natural liberty is the power of acting as one thinks fit, without any restraint or control, unless by the law of nature. 1 Bl. Comm. 125.
47g. All men are freemen or slaves. Inst. 1, 3, pr.; Fleta, 1. 1, c. 1, s. 2; Bouv. 145.
47f. He is to be judged impious and cruel who does not favor liberty. Co. Litt. 124.
47e. Liberty is more favored than all things [anything.] Dig. 50, 17, 122.
47d. Freedom does not admit of valuation. Bract. fol. 14. The body of a freeman does not admit of valuation. Dig. 9, 3, 7; Hob. 59.
47c. Liberty is an inestimable thing; a thing above price. Dig. 50, 17, 106.
47b. Liberty is that natural power of doing whatever one pleases, except that which is restrained by law or force. Co. Litt. 116.
47a. Whenever the interpretation of liberty is doubtful, the answer should be on the side of liberty. Dig. 50, 17, 20; Co. Litt. 116.

46d. Where the law prescribes a form, the nonobservance of it is fatal to the proceeding, and the whole becomes a nullity. Best, Ev. Introd. s. 59.
46c. Where form is not observed, a nullity of the act is inferred or follows. 12 Coke, 7.
46b. Legal form is essential form. 10 Coke, 100.
46a. Form gives being. Called "the old physical maxim." Black's, 514.

45h. Fiction is a poor ground for changing substantial rights. C.L.M.
45g. Fiction of law is wrongful if it works loss or injury to any one. 2 Coke, 35; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 122.
45f. Fictions arise from the law, and not law from fictions. Bouv. 136.
45e. The law makes use of a fiction where equity subsists. 11 Coke, 90.
45d. In the fiction of law there is always equity; a legal fiction is always consistent with equity. 11 Coke, 51a; Broom, Max. 127, 130.
45c. A fiction of law injures no one. 3 Coke, 36; 3 Bl. Comm. 43.
45b. A fiction is a rule of law that assumes something which is or may be false as true. Hibberd v. Smith, 67 Cal. 547; 4 Pac. 473.
45a. Where truth is, fiction of law does not exist. Black's 494; Bouv. 127.

44r. In a criminal matter, the act does not make a person guilty unless intention be guilty also. Broom, Max. 270, 275; 7 Term. 514; 4 N.Y. 159, 163; 2 Bouv. Inst. note 2211.
44q. Want of skill is reckoned as culpa; that is, as blamable conduct or neglect. Dig. 50, 15, 132.

44o. Impossibility is an excuse in the law. Co. Litt. 29; Broom, Max. 223.

44m. The law holds him excused who chose that his blood should be redeemed on any terms. Dig. 48, 21, 1; 1 Bl. Comm. 131.
44l. Misconduct binds [should bind] its own authors. It is a never-failing axiom that everyone is accountable only for his own offense or wrong. Ersk. Inst. 4, 1, 14.
44k. Simplicity is favorable to the law, and too much subtlety is blameworthy in law. 4 Coke, 8.
44j. Where the fault is mutual, the law will leave the case as it finds it. Story, Ag. s. 195.
44i. The rule is, that ignorance of the law does not excuse, but that ignorance of a fact may excuse a party from the legal consequences of his conduct. Dig. 22, 6, 9; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 232.
44h. He who does not blame, approves. 3 Inst. 27.
44g. A frivolous fear is not a legal excuse. Dig. 50, 17, 184; 2 Inst. 483.
44f. He adds fault to fault who sets up a defense of a wrong committed by him. 5 Coke, 49.
44e. Gross negligence is held equivalent to intentional wrong. Black's, 2d. 304.
44d. Obedience to existing laws is a sufficient extenuation of guilt before a civil tribunal. Broom, Max. 12, note.
44c. No guilt attaches to him who is compelled to obey. Dig. 50, 17, 169, pr.; Bouv. 124.
44b. It is a fault for any one to meddle in a matter not pertaining to him, or with a thing not belonging to him. 2 Inst. 208; Dig. 50, 17, 36.
44a. He is clear of blame who knows, but cannot prevent. Dig. 50, 15, 50.

43h. The expression of things of which, if unexpressed, one would have the benefit, is useless. 4 Coke, 73.
43g. Many things can be implied from a few expressions. Litt. s. 384.
43f. A general expression implies nothing certain. Wing. Max. 164.
43e. Things expressed may be prejudicial; things not expressed are not. Dig. 50, 17, 19, 5; Dig. 35, 1, 52.
43d. That which is expressed puts an end to (renders ineffective) that which is implied. 4 Coke, 80; Broom, Max. 651; Weston v. Davis, 24 Me. 374.
43c. A general expression is to be interpreted generally. 8 Coke, 116a.

42f. Failure to enforce the law does not change it. Louisville & N. R.R. v. U S., 282 U.S. 740, 759.
42e. The execution of law does no injury. 2 Rolle. 301.
42d. Executions [of law] are preferred to all other processes whatever. Co. Litt. 287, 289.
42c. The effect of a law consists in the execution. Co. Litt. 2896.
42b. Execution is the end and the fruit of the law, and is very aptly called the life of the law. Co. Litt. 289; Bank of U.S. v. Halstead, 10 Wheat. (23U.S.) 51, 64.
42a. Execution is the execution of the law according to the judgment. 3 Inst. 212.

41e. Surplusage does not usually vitiate writings. Dig. 50, 17, 94.
41d. Surplusage does not spoil the remaining part if that is good in itself. Dyer, 392; Broom, Max. 627.
41c. Surplusage does no harm. 3 Bouv. Inst. no. 2949; Broom, Max. 627; Jenk. Cent. 184.
41b. What ever is done in excess is prohibited by law. 2 Inst. 107.
41a. Excess in law is reprehended. Excess in anything is reprehended at common law. Co. Litt. 44.

40g. It is proper that laws be greater than any exception. Halk. Max 74.
40f. An exception which confirms the law, expounds the law. 2 Bulstr. 189.
40e. The exception proves the rule. 11 Coke, 41; 3 Term, 722.
40d. An exception should always be put last. 9 Coke, 53.
40c. Every exception is itself also a rule. Every rule is liable to its own exceptions. Black's, 852.
40b. An exception proves the rule concerning things not excepted. 11 Coke, 41; Bacon, Aph. 17.
40a. The exception affirms the rule to be the other way. Bacon, Aph.
