39ii. No one alleging his own turpitude, or who wishes to perish, is to be heard as a witness. 4 Inst. 279; Best. Ex. s. 385.
39hh. The rules of evidence are of great importance, and cannot be departed without endangering private as well as public rights. Nicholls v. Webb, 8 Wheat. (21 U.S.) 326, 332.
39gg. Judicial notice is a form of evidence. Mann v. Mann, 172 P.2d 369, 375, 76 Ca].App.2d 32.
39ff. Evidence does not consist of vague, uncertain, irrelevant matter not carrying the quality of proof to induce conviction. McDonald v. Robertson, 104 F.2d 945, 948.
39ee. A witness is a person who is present at and observes a transaction. State v. Desforges, 47 La. Ann. 1167; 17 So. 811.
39dd. The power of proofs [or the right of offering proof or giving testimony] is not to be narrowed. 4 Inst. 279.

39cc. Report, which induces suspicion, ought to arise from good and grave men; not, indeed, from malevolent and malicious men, but from cautious and credible persons; not only once, but frequently; for clamor diminishes, and defamation manifests. 2 Inst. 52; Black's, 2d. 482.
39bb. When the proofs of facts are present, what need is there of words? 2 Bulst. 53; Bouv. 122.

39aa. Any person skilled in his peculiar art or profession is to be believed, [i.e., when he speaks of matters connected with such art.] Co. Litt. 125a; 1 Bl. Comm. 75. Credence should be given to one skilled in his peculiar profession. Broom, Max. 932; Dickinson v. Barber, 9 Mass. 227; 6 Am. Dec. 58.
39z. What is not proved and what does not exist are the same; it is not a defect of the law, but of proof. Black's, 587; Jenk. Cent. 207.
39y. Principles prove, they are not proved. 3 Coke, 40. Fundamental principles require no proof; or, in Lord Coke's words, "they ought to be approved, because they cannot be proved." 3 Coke, 50a.
39x. Witnesses are weighed, not counted. That is, the more worthy or credible are to be believed. 1 Starkie, Ev. 554; Best, Ev. p. 426, s. 389; Bakeman v. Rose, 14 Wend. (N.Y.) 105, 109.
39w. One eye-witness is of more weight than ten ear-witnesses, [or those who speak from hearsay.] 4 Inst. 279; 3 Bouv. Inst. n. 3154.
39v. All things are presumed to be lawfully done and duly performed until the contrary is proved. Co. Litt. 232b; Id. 6; Best, Ev. p. 337, s. 300; Bank of U.S. v. Dandridge, 12 Wheat. 64, 69-70.

39u. It is vain to prove that which if proved would not aid the matter in question. Broom, Max. 3d. Lond. ed. 255; Halk. Max. 50. That cannot be proved which proved is irrelevant. 1 Exch. 91, 92, 102.
39t. All things are presumed against a despoiler or wrong-doer. (A leading maxim in the law of evidence.) Best, Ev. p. 340, s. 303; Broom, Max. 938.
39s. The extremes being proved, intermediate things are presumed. Tray. Leg. Max. 207; 1 Greenl. Ev. s. 20.
39r. Proofs ought to be evident, to-wit, clear and easily understood. Co. Litt. 283.
39q. Things manifest and plain truths do not require proof. 7 Coke, 40b; Co. Litt. 16.
39p. A witness alleging contrary or contradictory things (whose statements contradict each other) is not to be heard. 4 Inst. 279.
39o. What is proved by record ought not to be denied. Black's, 986.

39n. The burden of proof lies on him who asserts the fact, not on him who denies it; as from the nature of things, he who denies a fact cannot produce any proof. Steph. Pl. 84; Dig. 22, 3, 2; 1 Greenl. Ev. s. 74; Dranguet v. Prudhomme, 3 La. 83; 4 Bouv. Inst. n. 4411.
39m. Witnesses cannot testify to a negative; they must testify to an affirmative. 4 Inst. 279.

39l. The answer of one witness shall not be heard at all; the testimony of a single witness shall not be admitted under any circumstances (for civil cases). 1 Greenl. Ev. s. 260; Code. 4, 20, 9; 3 Bl. Comm. 370; Best, Ev. p. 426, s. 390, and note.
39k. He who affirms must prove. Porter v. Stevens, 9 Cush. (Mass.) 535.
39j. It is in the nature of things that a negative is no proof. Black's, 2d. 890; Bouv. 147; Code. 4, 19, 23.
39i. That which appears to the court needs not the aid of witnesses. 2 Inst. 662.
39h. What is clearly apparent need not be proved. 10 Mod. 150. The law does not require that to be proved which is apparent to the court. 9 Coke, 54.
39g. The law arises out of the fact. 2 Inst. 479; 2 Bl. Comm. 329.
39f. Nothing can be treated as evidence which is not introduced as such. Harvey v. Waitt, 44 N.E.2d 629, 633, 312 Mass. 333.
39e. In criminal cases, the proofs should be clearer than the light. 3 Inst. 210.
39d. Proof is the effect of evidence; the establishment of a fact by evidence. Tift v. Jones, 77 Ga. 181; 3 S.E. 399.
39c. No one ought to be a witness in his own cause. 3 Bl. Comm. 371. No person is understood to be a competent witness in his own cause. Dig. 22, 5, 10.
39b. A confession made in court is of greater effect than any proof. Jenk. Cent. 102; 11 Coke, 30.
39a. Things done in one action cannot be taken as evidence in another, unless it be between the same parties. Tray. Leg. Max. 11.
39. EVIDENCE, PROOF & WITNESSES
38d. The progress of events shows many things which, at the beginning, could not be guarded against or foreseen. 6 Coke, 40.
38c. An event is vainly expected from which no effect follows. Black's, 2d. 527.
38b. A new matter always produces various events. Co. Litt. 379.
38a. An event is that which follows from the cause, and is called an "event" because it eventuates from cause. 9 Coke, 81.
38. EVENT
37n. The multitude of those who err is no protection (or excuse) for error. 11 Coke, 75.
37m. Error dwells in general expressions. Pitman v. Hooper, 3 Sumn. 290, Fed. Cas. No. 11,186; Underwood v. Carney, 1 Cush. (Mass.) 292.
37l. The mistakes of the writer ought not to harm. Jenk. Cent. 324.
37k. The denial of a conclusion is error in law. Wing. Max. 268.
37j. To refer errors to their sources is to refute them. 3 Inst. 15.
37i. A man is presumed to be simple [minded] who makes a mistake in his own name. Code. 6, 24, 14; Van Alst v. Hunter, 5 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 148, 161.
37h. The people is the greatest master of error. Bacon; Black's, 767; Cycl. Dict. 649.
37g. An error made by a clerk should not injure or prejudice; a clerical error may be corrected. Jenk. Cent. 23, 324; Dig. 34, 5, 3.
37f. False in one thing, false in every thing. The Santissima Trinidad, 7 Wheat. (20 U.S.) 283, 339.
37e. It is safer to err on the gentler side or the side of mercy. 3 Inst. 220.
37d. An error which is not resisted or opposed is approved. Bout). 125. (37)
37c. Every consent removes error. Consent always removes the effect error. 2 Inst. 123.

37b. Error of law injures. A mistake of the law has an injurious effect; that is, the party committing it must suffer the consequences. Mackeld. Rom. Law, s. 178; 1 Story, Eq. Jur. s. 139, note; 4 Bout). Inst. n. 3828.
37a. Error artfully disguised [or colored] is, in many instances, more probable than naked truth; and frequently error overwhelms truth by its show of reason. 2 Coke, 73.
37. ERROR, MISTAKE (See also: FAULT -:- FICTION)
36s. Laws derived from the pure source of equity and justice must be founded on the consent of those whose obedience they require. C.L.M.
36r. Equity follows the law. Talb. 52; Story, Eq. Jur. s .64. Co. Litt. 24b; Broom, Max. 151; Wood. Lect. 479.
36q. He who is placed out of the law is civilly dead. Co. Litt. 130.
36p. Equity suffers not a wrong without a remedy 4 Bout). Inst. no. 3726.
36o. Equity never counteracts the laws. Black's, 2d. 45.
36n. Equity looks upon that as done, which ought to be done. 4 Bout). Inst. n. 3729; Craig v. Leslie, 3 Wheat. (16 U.S.) 563, 578.
36m. In all things, but especially in law, equity is to be regarded. Dig. 50, 17, 90; Story, Bailm. s. 257.
36l. The court of chancery is the workshop of justice. 2 Inst. 552.
36k. Equity is as it were equality; equity is a species of equality or equalization. Co. Litt. 24; Bout). Inst. 3725; 1 Story, Eq. Jur. s. 64.
36j. Equity is a certain perfect reason, which interprets and amends the written law, comprehended in no writing, but consisting in right reason alone. Co. Litt. 24b.
36i. Law regards equity. Co. Litt. 24b; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 143.
36h. The civil law is what a people establishes for itself. Inst. 1, 2, 1; Jackson v. Jackson, 1 Johns. (N.Y.) 424, 426.
36g. Nothing is more unjust than to extend equity too far. Halk. 103.

36f. In the court of chancery (equity) a man shall not be prejudiced by his mispleading, or defect of form, but according to the truth of the matter; for the decision should be made according to conscience and not according to the rigor of law. C.L.M.
36e. Equity is the correction of that wherein the law, by reason of its generality, is deficient. Plowd. 375, 467.
36d. Equity does not make law, but assists law. Lofft, 379.
36c. Equity acts upon the person. 4 Bouv. Inst. n. 3733.
36b. He who prefers a charge against another, however just it may be, will himself be unjust unless the accused be heard in his own defense. C.L.M.
36a. A court of equity ought to do justice completely and not by halves. Rice &Adams Corp. v. Lathrop, 278 U.S. 509, 515.
36. EQUITY & CIVIL PRACTICES
35x. What one has paid knowing it not to be due, with intention of recovering it back, he cannot recover back. Dig. 2, 6, 50.
35w. Money (pecunia) is so called from cattle, (pecus,) because all the wealth of our ancestors consisted in cattle. Co. Litt. 207.
35v. No one is prohibited from following several kinds of businesses or several arts. 11 Coke, 54a.
35u. It is natural that he who bears the charge of a thing should receive the profits. Dig. 50, 17, 10.
35t. Services which are incapable of division are to be performed in whole by each individual. 6 Coke, 1.
35s. Usury is odious in law. Bouv. 161.
35r. The value of a thing is estimated according to its worth in money, but the value of money is not estimated by reference to a thing. 9 Coke, 76.
35q. He at whose risk a thing is done, should receive the profits arising from it. Black's, 2d. 1182.
35p. For concerning anything which occurs without deceit or wrong on the part of the vendor, the vendor is secure. Brown v. Bellows, 4 Pick. (Mass.) 198.
35o. It is inequitable to permit some to trade and to prohibit others. 3 Inst. 181.
35n. A sacred thing does not admit of valuation. Dig. 1, 8, 9, 5.
35m. The words "current money" designate current at the time of payment. Day. 20; Black's, 2d. 1200.
35l. Those things which rarely happen are not to be taken into account in the transaction of business, without sufficient reason. Dig. 50, 17, 64.
35k. Cause and origin is the material of business. 1 Coke, 99; Wing. Max. max. 41, 21.
35j. A workman for hire promises the skill of his art; he engages to do the work in a skillful or workmanlike manner. 2 Kent, Comm. 588; Story, Bailm. s. 428.
35i. Merchandise is whatever can be sold. Baldwin v. Williams, 3 Metc. (Mass.) 365.
35h. The term `merchandise' belongs to movable things only. Dig. 50, 16, 66.
35g. Goods are worth as much as they can be sold for. Shep. Touch. 142; 3 Inst. 305.
35f. It is said to be monopoly when one person alone buys up the whole of one kind of commodity, fixing a price at his own pleasure. 11 Coke, 86.
35e. Money is the just medium and measure of commutable things, for by the medium of money a convenient and just estimation of all things is made. Day. Ir. KB. 18; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 922.
35d. Whatever money is paid, is paid according to the direction or intention of the payer; whatever money is received, is received according to that of the recipient. 2 Vern. 606; Broom, Max. 810.
35c. An insane person who knows not what he does cannot make a bargain, nor transact any business. 4 Coke, 126.
35b. Let every one employ himself in what he knows. 11 Coke, 10.
35a. Commerce ought to be common, and not to be converted into a monopoly and the private gain of a few. 3 Inst. 181, in marg.
34i. Right and obligation are considered by all ethical writers as correlative terms. Ogden v. Saunders, 25 U.S. 213, 281.
34h. A neglected duty often works as much against the interests as a duty wrongfully performed. Keim v. U. S., 177 U.S. 290, 295.
34g. No one is bound to do what is impossible. Black's 2.
34f. He who betrays his country is like the insane sailor who bores a hole in the ship which carries him. 3 Inst. 36.
34e. That which touches or concerns all ought to be supported by all. C.L.M.
34d. Those who do not preserve the law of the land, they justly incur the awesome and indelible brand of infamy. 3 Inst. 221.
34c. He who becomes a soldier of Christ has ceased to be a soldier of the world; nor is he entitled to any reward who acknowledges no duty. C.L.M.
34b. A man may obey the law and yet be neither honest nor a good neighbor. C.L.M.
34a. It is safe not to obey him who has no right. Hob. 146.
34a. DUTY (Of Individuals)
33f. Dower ought not to be sought from dower. 4 Coke, 122b.

33e. In law, a dower is a provision for a widow; upon her husband's death, out of his lands or tenements for her support and the nurture of her children. Co. Lilt. 30a; 2 Bl. Comm. 130; 4 Kent, Comm. 35; Chaplin v. Hill, 1 R.I. 452; Hoy v. Varner, 100 Va. 600, 42 S.E. 690.
33d. A woman leaving her husband of her own accord, and committing adultery, loses her dower, unless her husband takes her back of his own accord. Co. Litt. 37.
33c. A legitimate dower belongs to every woman of all lands and tenements of which her husband possessed in his own right, as of fee, etc. Co. Litt. 336; C.L.M.
33b. Where there is no marriage, there is no dower. 2 Bl. Comm. 130; Wait v. Wait, 4 Barb. (N.Y.) 192, 194; Co. Litt. 35a.
33a. The law favors dower; it is the reward of chastity; therefore let it be preserved. Co. Litt. 31; Jenk. Cent. 50; Branch, Princ.
33. DOWER (See Also: INHERITANCE -:- MARRIAGE)
32g. When you doubt about a thing, do not do it. 1 Hale P.C. 310.
32f. In doubt, the gentler or safer course is to be followed. Bouv. 130.
32e. In a doubtful matter, the negative is to be understood [or regarded] rather than the affirmative. Godb. 37; Cycl. Dict. 518.
32d. In a doubtful case, that is the construction of the law which the words indicate. Bouv. 130.
32c. Inquire into doubtful points if you wish to understand the law well; because by reasoning we arrive at legal reason. Litt. s. 443.
32b. In doubtful cases, there is no presumption in favor of the will. Cro. Car. 51.
32a. In doubtful cases, the more worthy or favorable are to be taken. Branch, Princ.; Dig. 50, 17, 56; 2 Kent, Comm. 557.
32. DOUBT, DOUBTFUL (See Also: AMBIGUITY -:- CERTAINTY)
31j. A description which distinguishes it from any other, although a better or still more certain description might be given, is all that is required. Matson v. Hord, 1 Wheat. (14 U.S.) 130, 138.
31i. The purpose of a description is to afford the means to identify the subject matter. Mitchell v. Moore, 13 So.2d 314, 317, 152 Fla. 843.
31h. To define is to determine with precision or to exhibit clearly the boundaries thereof. Deal v. Enon Sanitary Dist., 95 S.E.2d 362, 366, 245 N.C. 74.
31g. Discretion is to discern through law what is just. 5 Coke, 99, 100; 4 Inst. 41; 1 Bl. Comm. 152; 3 Bulstr. 128.
31f. The undefined supplies the place of the whole. 4 Coke, 77.
31e. Whatever is added to the description of a thing already sufficiently described is of no effect. Dig. 33, 4, 1, 8; Broom, Max. 562.
31d. A false description does not vitiate. 6 Term. 676; 1 Greenl. Ev. s. 301; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 562.
31c. Every definition in law is perilous, for it is on the verge of being subverted. Dig. 50, 17, 202; 2 Wood. Lect. 196.
31b. He who describes and distinguishes well teaches well. 2 Inst. 470.

31a. False description does not injure or vitiate, provided the thing or person intended has once been sufficiently described. Mere false description does not make an instrument inoperative. Broom, Max. 629; 6 Term, 676; Cleveland v. Smith, 2 Story, 291, Fed. Cas. No. 2,874.
31. DESCRIBE, DEFINE, DECERN
30n. The law arises from the deed. 2 Inst. 49.
30m. Delivery makes a deed speak. 5 Coke, la. Delivery gives effect to the words of a deed. Id.
30l. No man can contravene or contradict his own deed. 2 Inst. 66.
30k. The intention is to be taken for the deed. 3 Inst. 69; Broom, Max. 311.
30j. A deed is nothing else than the vestment of a gift. Co. Litt. 36.
30i. Bad or false grammar does not vitiate a deed or grant. C.L.M.; Shep. Touch. 55, 87; 9 Coke, 48a; Wing. Max. 19.
30h. When a deed contains a general clause, and afterwards descends to special words, consistent with the general clause, the deed is to be construed according to the special words. 8 Coke, 154.
30g. The deed of one should not hurt another. Co. Litt. 152.
30f. It is the tenor of the deed which gives validity to the fee. C.L.M.
30e. Authority to execute a deed must be given by deed. 4 Term, 313; Cooper v. Rankin, 5 Binn. (Penn.) 613.
30d. In the delivery of writings (i.e., deeds), not what is said but what is done is to be considered. 9 Coke, 137a.
30c. That is not called a "deed" which does not continue operative. 5 Coke, 96.
30b. Deeds contain many things which are prohibited to be done. 12 Coke, 124.
30a. Deeds are more powerful than words. Black's, 476.
30. DEEDS (Writings)
29y. He who acts fraudulently acts in vain. 2 Rolle, 17.
29x. Let no one be relieved or gain an advantage by his own fraud. C.L.M.
29w. No one is considered as deceiving those who know and consent to his acts. Dig. 50, 17, 145; Bouv. 141.
29v. Fraud is always positive or intentional and distinguished from negligence. Alexander v. Church, 53 Conn. 561; 4 Atl. 103.
29u. Let him who wishes to be deceived, be deceived. Broom, Max. 782, note; Shep. Touch. 56.
29t. Fraud and justice never dwell together. Wing. Max. 680. Right and fraud never live together. CycL Dict. 571.
29s. Fraud is odious, and not to be presumed. Cro. Car. 550; Bouv. 127.
29r. It is a fraud to conceal a fraud. 1 Story, Eq. Jur. s. 389, 390.
29q. He acts in fraud of the law who, though the letter of the law being inviolate, uses the law contrary to its intention. Dig. 1, 3, 29.
29p. Fraud is not purged by circuitry. Bac. Max. reg. 4; Broom, Max. 228; Noy, Max. 9, 12.
29o. Fraud lurks in generalities. Tray. Lat. Max. 162. Fraud deals in generalities. 2 Coke, 34a; 3 Coke, 81a.
29n. A new road, not an old one, often deceives the traveler. 4 Inst. 34.
29m. Deceit is an artifice, since it pretends one thing and does another. Black's, 387.
29l. Deceit and fraud shall not defend, excuse or benefit any man. Best, Evid. p. 469, s. 428; 1 Story, Eq. Jur. s 395; 3 Coke, 78; Fleta, lib. 1, c. 13, s. 15.
29k. He is not deceived who knows himself to be deceived. 5 Coke, 60.
29j. What otherwise is good and just, if it be sought by force and fraud, becomes bad and unjust. 3 Coke, 78.
29i. Once a fraud, always a fraud. 13 Vin. Abr. 539.
29h. Gross negligence is equivalent to fraud. Black's, 2d. 698; Dig. 11, 6, 1; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 646; McCracken v. Hare, 2 Spears (S.C.) 256.
29g. Out of fraud no action arises; A right of action cannot arise out of fraud. Phelps v. Decker, 10 Mass. 276. Broom, Max. 349.
29f. A deception practiced upon one person does not give a cause of action to another. Dig. 50, 17, 49.
29e. The fraud of a predecessor does not prejudice his successor. Black's, 2d. 387; Bouv. 124.
29d. Fraud should be proved by clear tokens. 1 Story, Cont. s. 625; Code. 2, 21, 6.
29c. A person deceiving deals in general terms. Wing. Max. 636; 2 Coke, 34a; Broom, Max. 289; 2 Bulstr. 226; Lofft. 782.
29b. It is safer to be deceived than to deceive. Lofft, 396.
29a. The laws help persons who are deceived, not those deceiving. Tray. Lat. Max. 149.
29. DECEIT, FRAUD
28aa. No one can owe to himself. Cycl. Dict. 689.
28z. The right of the creditors (to sue) can neither be taken away nor diminished by agreements among the debtors. Broom, Max. 697.

28y. A debtor is not presumed to make a gift. 1 Kames, Eq. 212; Dig. 50, 16, 10s. Where the debtor gives money or goods to his creditor, the natural presumption is that he means to get free from his obligation, and not to make a present, unless donation be expressed. Ersk. Inst. 3, 3, 93.
28x. A fire does not release a debtor from his debt. Code. 4, 2, 11.
28w. What one has paid knowing it not to be due, with the intention of recovering it back, he cannot recover back. Dig. 2,6, 50.
28v. A debt is a legal relation between two parties. Safe Dep. & Tr. Co. v. Virginia, 280 U.S. 83, 97.
28u. The refusal of money tendered releases him who tenders it. 9 Coke, 79a.
28t. He does not pay who pays too late; for, from the delay, he is judged not to pay. Dig. 50, 16, 12, 1; Bouv. 139.
28s. Whatever is paid is to be applied according to the intention of the payer. 2 Vern. 606; Bouv. 152.
28r. The thing passes with its burden [or debt.] Where a thing has been encumbered by mortgage, the encumbrance follows it wherever it goes. Bract. fols. 47b, 48.
28q. Naked reason and naked promise do not bind any debtor. Fleta, 1, 2, c. 60, s. 25.
28p. In all obligations, in which no time or date is fixed for the payment, the debt is due on the present day; the liability accrues immediately. Dig. 50, 17, 14.
28o. If anything be owing to an entire body, it is not owing to the individual members; nor do the individuals owe that which is owing by the entire body. Dig. 3, 4, 7, 1.
28n. When two persons are liable concerning one and the same thing, if one makes default the other must bear the whole. 2 Inst. 277.
28m. Novation (the substitution of a new debt or obligation for an existing one) is not presumed in law. Halk. Lat. Max. 109.
28l. The principal should always be exhausted before coming upon the sureties. 2 Inst. 19.
28k. Debts follow the person of the debtor; that is, they have no locality, and may be collected wherever the debtor can be found. 2 Kent, Comm. 429; Story, Confl. Laws, s. 362.
28j. In alternatives, the debtor has the election. Black's, 599.
28i. That which is paid by the order of another is the same as though it were paid by him who ordered it. Dig. 50, 17, 180.
28h. That which is due unconditionally is due now. Tray. Leg. Max. 519.
28g. Let him who has nothing in his purse pay in his person, lest he who offends should go unpunished. C.L.M.; 2 Inst. 173; 4 Bl. Comm. 20.
28f. No one is considered to be solvent unless he can pay all that he owes. Dig. 50, 16, 114.
28e. A delegated debtor is hateful in law. 3 Bulstr. 148.
28d. Nothing can be demanded before the time when, by the nature of things, it can be paid. Dig. 50, 17, 186.
28c. Under the head of "creditors" are included, not only those who have lent money, but all to whom from any cause a debt is owing. Dig. 50, 16, 11.
28b. An evidence of debt not existing is presumed to have been discharged. Tray. Leg. Max. 73.
28a. An evidence of debt found in the debtor's possession is presumed to be paid. Halk. Max. 20; Black's, 198; Bouv. 120.
28. DEBT, DEBTOR, CREDITOR
27v. A custom of the truest antiquity is to be retained. 4 Coke, 78.
27u. Custom shall be taken [is to be construed] strictly. Jenk. Cent. 83.
27t. Custom leads the willing, law compels [draws] the unwilling. Jenk. Cent. 274.
27s. A custom once disallowed cannot be again brought forward, [or relied on.] Day. 33; Black's, 256.
27r. A prescriptive and lawful custom overcomes the law. Co. Litt. 113; 4 Coke, 21.
27q. General customs are such as prevail throughout a country and become the law of that country. Bodfish v. Fox, 23 Me. 95.
27p. The antiquity of a custom is to be less regarded that its reasonableness. Co. Litt. 141a.
27o. The custom of the place where the action is brought is to be observed. Decouche v. Savetier, 3 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 190, 219, 8 Am. Dec. 478.
27n. Custom is not drawn into consequence. Black's, 256.
27m. Custom can neither arise from nor be taken away by a wrong or injury. Lofft, 340.
27l. A reasonable custom is to be obeyed as a law. 4 Coke, 38.
27k. The custom of a manor and place is to be observed. Litt. s. 169; 6 Coke, 67; 4 Coke, 28b.
27j. Things which are done contrary to the custom and usage of our ancestors neither please nor appear right. 4 Coke, 78.
27i. A custom, though it be of great authority, should never prejudice manifest truth. 4 Coke, 18.
27h. A custom, grounded on a certain and reasonable cause, supersedes the common laws. Litt. s. 169; Co. Litt. 113; Broom, Max. 919.
27g. Reason is the formal cause of custom. Black's, 992. Reason is the source and mold of custom. Bouv. 155.
27f. Custom is more powerful than grant. Black's, 907.

27e. Custom is the best expounder (or interpreter) of the laws. 2 Inst. 18; 4 Inst. 75; McKeen v. Delano', 5 Cranch (9 U.S.) 32; Dig. 1, 3, 37; McFerran v. Powers, 1 Serg. & R. (Pa.) 106; Broom, Max. 931; Lofft, 237; Jenk. Cent. 273.
27d. Custom is another law. 4 Coke, 21. Custom is observed for law. Co. Litt. 113.
27c. A custom should be certain; for an uncertain custom is considered null. Day. 33; Black's, 255; Bouv. 121.
27b. A custom introduced against reason ought rather to be called a "usurpation" than a "custom." Co. Litt. 113.
27a. In those things which by common right are conceded to all, the custom of a particular district or place is not to be alleged. 11 Coke, 85.
27. CUSTOM See Also: COMMON LAW -:- LAW)

26dd. It is not just and proper that he who speaks ill of a bad man should be condemned on that account; for it is fitting and expedient that the crimes of bad men should be known. Dig. 47, 10, 17; 1 Bl. Comm. 125.
26cc. An outlaw is, as it were, put out of the protection of the law. 7 Coke, 14.

26bb. False in one thing, false in everything. Where a party is clearly shown to have embezzled one article of property, it is a ground of presumption that he may have embezzled others also. The Boston, 1 Sumn. 328, 356, Fed. Cas. No. 1,673; The Santissima Trinidad, 7 Wheat. 339; White v. Disher, 67 Cal. 402, 7 Pac. 826.
26aa. All crimes that are committed openly are lighter, [or have a less odious appearance than those committed secretly.] 8 Coke, 127a.
26z. The instigator of a crime is worse that he who perpetrates it. 5 Coke, 99.
26y. In high treason no one can be an accessory but only principal. 3 Inst. 138.
26x. The accessory does not precede, but follows the principal. Co. Litt. 152. C.L.M.

26w. The crime carries the person, (i.e., the commission of a crime gives the courts of the place where it is committed jurisdiction over the person of the offender.) People v. Adams, 3 Denio (N.Y.) 190, 210, 45 Am. Dec. 468.
26v. Capital crimes are punished by death. Walker v. State, 13 S.W. 860.
26u. The will and the proposed end distinguished crimes. Bract. fol. 2b, 136b. In crimes, the will, and not the consequence, is looked to. 2 Inst. 57.
26t. In criminal acts, the will will be taken for the deed. 3 Inst. 106.
26s. In criminal matters or cases, a general malice of intention is sufficient, [if united] with an act of equal or corresponding degree. Bacon, Max. p. 65, reg. 15; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 291.
26r. Crimes are extinguished by death. Black's, 2d, 300.
26q. Extortion is a crime when, by color of office, any person extorts that which is not due, or more than is due, or before the time when it is due. 10 Coke, 102.
26p. In offenses, the intention is regarded, not the event. Dig. 48, 8, 14; Bacon, Max. reg. 7.
26o. Crime vitiates everything which springs from it. Henry v. Bank of Salina, 5 Hill (N.Y.) 523, 531.
26n. If a man kill another, he is held guilty of felony. 3 Inst. 51.
26m. Facility of pardon is an incentive to crime. 4 Coke, 45. The hope of impunity holds out a continual temptation to crime. 3 Inst. 236.
26l. In more atrocious crimes the intent is punished, though an effect does not follow. 2 Rolle 82.
26k. Drunkenness both inflames (or aggravates) and reveals every crime. Co. Litt. 247a; 4 Bl. Comm. 26; Broom, Max. 17.
26j. He who is once criminal is presumed to be always criminal in the same kind or way. Cro. Car. 317; Best, Ev. 345.
26i. Felony is implied in every treason. 3 Inst. 15.
26h. No one shall be called a principal felon except the party actually committing the felony, or the party present aiding and abetting in its commission. 3 Inst. 138.
26g. No one is called an accessory after the fact but he who knew the principal to have committed a felony, and received and comforted him. 3 Inst. 138.
26f. Prevention is better than cure. Co. Litt. 304b.
26e. Felony, by force of the term, signifies a capital crime perpetrated with a malignant mind. Co. Litt. 391.
26d. The character of a past offense is never aggravated by a subsequent act or matter. Dig. 50, 17, 138, 1; Bacon, Max. reg. 8; Broom, Max. 42.
26c. The crime of treason exceeds all other crimes in its punishment. 3 Inst. 210; Black's, 2d. 300; Bouv. 122.
26b. One who is accessory to a crime cannot be guilty of a higher degree of crime than his principal. 3 Inst. 139.
26a. He who does not forbid a crime while he may, sanctions it. C.L.M.
26. CRIME, CRIMINAL ACTS (See also: PUNISHMENT -:- WRONG)
25f. Corruption is always the forerunner of despotism. Mequire v. Corwine, 11 Otto (101 U.S.) 108, 111-12.
25e. There may be an abuse of everything of which there is a use, virtue only excepted. Day. Ir. KB. 79.
25d. Corruption of the best is worst. Black's, 277.
25c. It is a poisonous gloss which corrupts the essence of the text. 11 Coke, 34.
25b. Things bad [or corrupted] in principle at the commencement improves not by lapse of time [does not achieve a good end.] Broom, Max. 178; 4 Coke, 2.
25a. It is not the rigor but the inexpediency of laws and acts of authority which make them tyrannical. C.L.M.
25. CORRUPT ACTS, CORRUPTION
24kk. In the contract of loan, a stipulation not to be liable for fraud is not valid. Dig. 13, 7, 17, pr.
24jj. A bond is released in the same manner by which it is contracted or bound. Co. Litt. 212b; Broom, Max. 891; Livingston v. Lynch, 4 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 582.
24ii. An obligation without a mutual and concurrent intention of the parties but which is implied or arising from the liability is a quasi contract. Woods v. Ayres, 39 Mich. 350; 33 Am. Rep. 396.
24hh. When the words and the mind agree, there is no place for interpretation. Black's, 2d. 974.

24gg. Liberal interpretations are to be made of deeds, so that the purpose may stand rather than fall; and every grant is to be taken most strongly against the grantor. Wallis v. Wallis, 4 Mass. 135, 3 Am. Dec. 210; Hayes v. Kershow, 1 Sandf. Ch (N.Y.) 258, 268; Jenk. Cent. 270; Broom, Max. 543.
24ff. He who contracts knows, or ought to know, the quality of the person with whom he contracts, otherwise he is not excusable. Dig. 50, 17, 19; Cycl. Dict. 839.
24ee. In agreements, the intention of the contracting parties, rather than the words used, should be regarded. Jackson v. Wilkinson, 17 Johns. (N.Y.) 150; 2 Kent, Comm. 555; Dig. 50, 16, 219.
24dd. From an illegal contract an action does not arise. Broom, Max. 742.
24cc. In contracts, when the question is what was agreed upon, the terms are to be interpreted against the party offering them. Dig. 45, 1, 38, 18; 2 Kent, Comm. 721.

24bb. Nudum pactum (a naked contract) is where there is no consideration except the agreement; and does not create an obligation. Plowd. 309; Broom, Max. 745, 750; Dig. 2, 14, 7, 4; 2 Bl. Comm. 445; Code. 4, 65, 27.
24aa. In all contracts, whether nominate or innominate, an exchange [of value, i.e., a consideration] is implied. Gravin. lib. 2, s. 12; 2 Bl. Comm. 444, note.
24z. A contract cannot arise out of an act radically wrong and illegal. 1 Term, 734; 3 Term, 422; Broom, Max. 734.
24y. That which bars those who have made a contract will bar their successors. Dig. 50, 17, 143.
24x. A madman [or lunatic] can make no contract. Dig. 50, 17, 5; 1 Story, Contr. 76

24w. Nothing is so natural as that an obligation should be dissolved by the same mode and principles in which it were contracted. Dig. 50, 17, 35; 2 Inst. 359, 360; Esmond v. Van Benschoten, 12 Barb. (N.Y.) 366, 375. Therefore, an obligation by words is taken away by words; an obligation of mere consent is dissolved by contrary consent. Broom, Max. 887.
24v. The beginning and cause of every contract must be considered. Dig. 17, 1, 8; Story, Bail m . s. 56.
24u. An individual's power to contract is unlimited. Hale v. Henkel, 201 U.S. 43, 74.
24t. The stipulations of parties constitute the law of the contract. Hob. 118.

24s. That which is the less is held to be imported into the contract; (i.e., A. offers to hire B.'s house at six hundred dollars, at the same time B. offers to let it for five hundred dollars; the contract is for five hundred dollars.) 1 Story, Cont. 481; Dig. 50, 17, 9.
24r. By a contract something is permitted, which without it, could not be admitted. Co. Litt. 166.
24q. Contracts receive legal sanction from the agreement of the parties. Dig. 16, 3, 1, 6.

24p. A contract founded on a base consideration, or against good morals, is null and cannot be enforced by action. Hob. 167; Broom, Max. 730, 732; Story, Ag. s. 195; Dig. 2, 14, 27, 4; Code. 2, 3, 6; Bank of U.S. v. Owens, 2 Peters. 539; 2 Kent, Comm. 466.
24o. Equal knowledge on both sides makes contracting parties equal. 3 Burrows, 1905.

24n. In contracts, matters of custom and usage are tacitly implied. A contract is understood to contain the customary clauses, although they are not expressed. Story, Bills, s. 143; 3 Kent, Comm. 260, note; Broom, Max. 842.
24m. Contracts which are not illegal, and do not originate in fraud, must in all respects be observed. Code. 2, 3, 29; Broom, Max. 624.
24l. Compacts usually take their clothing from the thing itself, from words, from writing, from consent, from delivery. Plowd. 161.
24k. The contract makes the law. Black's, 2d. 704; Bouv. 135; Allen v. Merch. Bank of N.Y., 22 Wend. (N.Y.) 215, 233.
24j. In contracts, the truth of the matter ought to be regarded rather than the writing. Code. 4, 22, 1.
24i. Private contracts (or agreements) cannot derogate from public law or right. Broom, Max. 695; 7 Coke, 23; Wing. Max. max. 201; Co. Litt. 166a; Dig. 50, 17, 45, 1.
24h. In stipulations [within contracts,] the time when we contract is regarded. Dig. 50, 17, 144, 1.
24g. The place of the contract governs the act. 2 Kent, Comm. 458.

24f. A contract without consideration, or upon a false consideration, (which fails,) or upon unlawful consideration, cannot have any effect. Code. 3, 3, 4; Chit. Cont. (11th Am. Ed.) 25, note; Noy, Max. 24; 2 BL Comm. 445; 1 Story, Contr. s. 525.

24e. Contracts have no locality. The obligation of a contract is purely personal, and actions to enforce it may be brought anywhere. 2 Inst. 231; 1 Smith, Lead. Cas. 340, 363; Story, Confl. Laws, s. 362.
24d. Words spoken vanish, words written remain. A written contract cannot be varied by parol proof. Broom, Max. 3d Lond, ed. 594.
24c. An obligation which arises from contract, or quasi contract, is dissolved in the same way in which it was contracted. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 60, s. 19.
24b. A contract is, as it were, act against act. 2 Coke, 15.
24a. An action cannot be founded on a barren or unconditional contract. C.L.M.
24. CONTRACTS (See also: AGREE -:- DEEDS)
23d. That is continuing which is enduring, not terminated by a single act or fact. Black's, 2d 260.
23c. That which is so persistently repeated as to constitute virtually an unbroken series is continuous. Ingraham v. Hough, 46 N.C. 43.
23b. It gains strength by continuance. Mann v. Mann Ex'rs, 1 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 231, 237.
23a. To discontinue signifies nothing else than to intermit, to disuse, to interrupt. Co. Litt. 325.
23. CONTINUE, DISCONTINUE
22nn. That kind of interpretation which is born or drawn from the bowels of a cause is the fittest and most powerful in the law. 10 Coke, 24b.
22mm. In penal causes or cases, the more favorable interpretation should be adopted. Dig. 50, 17, 155, 2; Plowd. 86b, 124; 2 Hale, P.C. 365.
22ll. The language of a statute is to be understood and interpreted like ordinary spoken language. 10 Coke, 101b.
22kk. The best mode of interpretation is to interpret laws so that they may accord with each other. 8 Coke, 169.
22jj. The whole instrument is to be viewed and compared in all its parts, so that every part of it maybe made consistent and effectual. 2 Kent, Comm. 555; 2 Inst. 317; Wing. Max. 238.
22ii. Every interpretation either declares, extends, or restrains. Black's, 2d. 852; Bouv. 146.
22hh. When in the words there is no ambiguity, then no exposition contrary to the words is to be made. Co. Litt. 147.
22gg. Whenever the same language expresses two meanings, that should be adopted which is the better fitted for carrying out the subject-matter. Dig. 50, 17, 67.
22ff. In obscure constructions we always apply that which is the least obscure. Dig. 50, 17, 9; Broom, Max. 687n.
22ee. Use or usage is the best interpreter of things. 2 Inst. 282; Broom, Max. 917, 930, 931.
22dd. Every interpretation, if it can be done, is to be so made in instruments that all contradictions may be removed. Jenk. Cent. 96.
22cc. Words are to be interpreted according to the subject-matter. 6 Coke, 6, n.
22bb. The best interpreter of a statute is (all its parts being considered) the statute itself. Wing. Max. p. 239, max. 68; 8 Coke, 117b.
22aa. That interpretation is to be received [or adopted] which is free from fault [or wrong.] The law will not intend a wrong. Bacon, Max. 17, in reg. 3; Bouv. 124.

22z. Contemporaneous exposition is the best and strongest in the law. 2 Inst. 11; 3 Coke, 7. A statute is best explained by following the construction put upon it by judges who lived at the time it was made, or soon after. 10 Coke, 70; Broom, Max. 682.
22y. In doubt, the milder or safer course is to be followed. Black's, 2d. 601.

22x. Constructions of written instruments are to be made liberally, on account of the simplicity of the laity, [or common people,] in order that the thing [or subject-matter] may rather have effect than perish, [or become void.] Co. Litt. 36a; Broom, Max. 540; 2 Bl. Comm. 379; 1 Bulst. 175; Hob. 304.
22w. The best interpretation is made from antecedents and consequents. Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 513; 2 Inst. 317; 2 B!. Comm. 379. 1 Bulstr. 101.
22v. In dubious cases, the more favorable or worthy views are to be preferred; the more liberal constructions are always to be followed. Dig. 50, 17, 56; 2 Kent, Comm. 556.
22u. A curious [overnice or subtle] and captious interpretation in the law is to be reproved. 1 Bulst. 6; Bouv. 122.
22t. Things which have had a certain interpretation [whose interpretation has been settled, as by common opinion] are not to be altered. Co. Litt. 365; Wing. Max. p. 748, max. 202.
22s. That is a cursed interpretation which corrupts the text. 4 Coke, 35a; Broom, Max. 622.

22r. In the construction of agreements, words are interpreted against the person using them. Thus, the construction of the stipulatio is against the stipulator, and the construction of the promissio against the promissor. Dig. 45, 1, 38, 18; Broom, Max. 599.
22q. Law construes things according to common possibility or intendment. Wing. Max. p. 705, max. 189.
22p. An absolute, unqualified sentence (or proposition) needs no expositor. 2 Inst. 533.
22o. To make laws agree or harmonize with laws is the best mode of interpreting them. Halk. Max. 70; 8 Coke, 169a.
22n. Interpretation is always to be made in such a manner that what is absurd and inconvenient may be avoided, and the judgment be not nugatory or illusory. 1 Coke, 52.
22m. That is a guess, not an interpretation, which altogether departs from the letter. Bacon, Max. 18, (in reg. 3).
22l. Examples illustrate, but do not restrain, the law. Co. Litt. 240.
22k. The most benignant interpretation is to be made in restitutions. Co. Litt. 112.
22j. He who considers merely the letter of an instrument goes but skin deep into its meaning. Co. Litt. 289; Broom, Max. 685.
22i. The construction or explanation should arise out of the whole subject-matter. Wing. Max. 238.
22h. The best interpretation is made from things preceding and following; i.e., the context. 1 Rolle, 375.
22g. In contracts, the interpretation is to be liberal; in wills, more liberal; in restitutions, most liberal. Co. Litt. 112a.
22f. In the construction of words, not the mere words, but the thing and the meaning, are to be inquired after. Jenk. Cent. 132.
22e. The construction of the law (a construction made by the law) works no injury. The law will make such a construction of an instrument as not to injure a party. Co. Liu. 183; Broom, Max. 603.
22d. The more favorable construction is to be placed on general or doubtful expressions. 4 Coke, 15; Dig. 50, 17, 192, 1; 2 Kent, Comm. 557.
22c. It is his to interpret whose it is to enact. Tayl. Civil. Law, 96.
22b. Laws are to be more liberally interpreted, in order that their intent may be preserved. Dig. 1, 3, 18, 16.
22a. The construction of law obtains the force of law. Branch, Princ.
22. CONSTRUCTION & INTERPRETATION (See also: INTENT -:- WORDS & MEANINGS)
21s. Consent (acquiescence) removes mistake or error. Co. Litt. 126; 2 Inst. 123; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 129.
21r. He who does not disapprove when he can approves. 3 Inst. 27.
21q. They who consent to an act, and they who do it, shall be visited with equal punishment. 5 Coke, 80.
21p. Consent is the united will of several persons interested in one subject-matter. Davis, 48; Branch, Princ; Lofft, 514.
21o. He does not appear to have retained his consent, who has changed anything at the command of a party threatening. Broom, Max. 278; Bacon, Max. reg. 22.
21n. He who is silent does not indeed confess, but yet it is true that he does not deny. Dig. 50, 17, 142.
21m. He who mistakes is not considered as consenting. Bract. fol. 44; Dig. 50, 17, 116, s. 2; Broom, Max. 262; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 581; 2 Kent, Comm. 477; Greer v. Caldwell, 14 Ga. 207.
21l. The silence of a party implies his consent, when his interest is at stake. Jenk. Cent. p. 32, case 64; Broom, Max. 138, 787; 9 Mod. 38.
21k. He who consents cannot receive an injury. Broom, Max. 268, 269, 271, 395; Wing. Max.. 482; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 2279; Plowd. 501.
21j. It is immaterial whether a man gives his assent by words or by acts and deeds. 10 Coke, 52.
21i. Nothing is so contrary to consent as force and fear. Dig. 50, 17, 116.
21h. Long sufferance is construed as consent. Fleta, lib. 4, c. 26, s. 4.
21g. What I accept I do not reject. Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 636.
21f. He who does not forbid what he can forbid, seems to assent. 2 Inst. 308; 8 Exch. 304; 1 Bl. Comm. 430.
21e. Consent—A concurrence of wills. Black's, 2d 249.
21d. He who can will [exercise volition,] has a right to refuse to will, [to withhold consent.] Dig. 50, 7, 3.
21c. He may consent tacitly who may consent expressly. Dig. 50, 17, 3.
21b. Consent makes the law. Branch, Princ.; Black's, 2d. 248.
21a. Every consent involves a submission; but a mere submission does not necessarily involve consent. Black's, 2d. 249.
21. CONSENT (See also: AGREE -:- CONSENT)
20i. Confirmation supplies all defects, though that which had been done was not valid at the beginning. Co. Litt. 295b.
20h. Confirmation is void where the preceding gift is invalid. Moore, 764; Co. Litt. 295.

20g. Confirmation is not valid unless he who confirms is either in possession of the thing itself or of the right of which confirmation is to be made, and, in like manner, unless he to whom confirmation is made is in possession. Co. Litt. 295.
20f. He who confirms does not give. 2 Bouv. Inst. no. 2069..
20e. There are two instruments for confirming or impugning all things, —reason and authority. 8 Coke, 16.
20d. An exception which confirms the law explains the law. 2 Bulst. 189.
20c. He confirms the use of a thing who removes the abuse of it. Moore, 764.
20b. No one can confirm before the right accrues to him. 10 Coke, 48.
20a. To confirm is to make firm that which was before infirm. Co. Litt. 295.
20. CONFIRM, CONFIRMATION
19f. No one can improve his condition by his own wrong. Dig. 50, 17, 134, 1.
19e. Any conditions are odious, but especially those which are against [in restraint of] marriage and commerce. Lofft, App., 644.
19d. A condition precedent must be fulfilled before the effect can follow. Co. Litt. 201.
19c. An unlawful condition is deemed as not annexed. Black's, 2d. 239.
19b. It is called a "condition," when something is given on an uncertain event, which may or may not come into existence. Co. Litt. 201.
19a. A beneficial condition, which creates an estate, ought to be construed favorably, according to the intention of the words. 8 Coke, 90.
19. CONDITION
18g. An affirmative statute does not take from the common law. Jenk. Cent. 24.
18f. A dispensation is a wound, which wounds common law. Day. Ir. K B. 69.
18e. The custom of all the country is the common law of the country. Jenk. Cent. 119.
18d. What ever is inserted for the purpose of removing doubt and ambiguity does not hurt or affect the common law. Co. Litt. 205; Dig. 50, 17, 81.
18c. Things derogatory to the common law are not to be drawn into precedent. Branch, Princ.
18b. The jurisprudence of the common law is a science social and comprehensive. 7 Coke, 28a.
18a. Those things which are derogatory to the common law are to be strictly interpreted. Jenk. Cent. 29; Id. p. 221, case 72.
17g. The law dispenses what common use has approved. C.L.M.
17f. Custom and common usage overcomes the unwritten law, if it be special; and interprets the written law, if the law be general. Jenk. Cent. 273.

17e. Common knowledge includes matters of learning, experience, history, and facts of which judicial notice may be taken, and may be referred to in argument of counsel. Shelley v. Chilton's Adm'r, 32 S.W.2d 974, 977; 236 Ky. 221.
17d. Common error sometimes passes current as law. Broom, Max. 139, 140.
17c. Common opinion is good authority in law. Co. Litt. 186a; Bank of Utica v. Mersereau, 3 Barb. Ch. (N.Y.) 528, 577, 49 Am. Dec. 189.
17b. Names of things ought to be understood according to common usage, not according to the opinions of individuals. Dig. 33. 10. 7. 2.
17a. There should be no departure from a common observance or common usage. 2 Coke, 74; Co. Litt. 186a, 229b; Wing. Max. 203.
17a. COMMON KNOWLEDGE & USAGE

16i. A useless clause [one which expresses no more than the law by intendment would have supplied] is not supported by a remote presumption, or by a cause arising afterwards. Bacon, Max. 82, reg. 21; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 599.
16h. Particular clauses inserted in agreements to avoid doubts and ambiguity do not prejudice the general law. Dig. 50, 17, 81.
16g. When a provision of the party is wanting, the provision of the law is at hand. 6 Yin. Abr. 49.
16f. Special clauses are comprised in general ones. Dig. 50, 17, 147.
16e. A proviso is to provide for the present or future, not the past. 2 Coke, 72; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 275.
16d. Unusual clauses always excite a suspicion. 3 Coke, 81; Broom, Max. 3d. Lond. ed. 264.
16c. Words to which reference is made in an instrument have the same effect and operation as if they were inserted in the clause referring to them. Co. Litt. 359; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 599.
16b. A clause in a law which precludes its abrogation is void from the beginning. Bacon, Max. reg 19; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 27.
16a. A general clause does not extend to those things which are previously provided for specially. Lofft, App. 419; 8 Coke, 154b.
16. CLAUSE, PROVISION
15m. Too great certainty destroys certainty itself. Lofft, 244.
15l. That which is certain is fixed or stated, precise or exact, free from doubt or question. C.L.M.
15k. There must be sufficient positive facts proved to take a matter out of the realm of conjecture and presumption to that of certainty. Reynolds v. Blaisdell, 49A. 42, 43, 23 R.I. 16.
15j. An uncertain quantity vitiates the act. 1 Rolle, 465.
15i. It is a miserable state of things where the law is vague and uncertain. 2 Salk. 512; Bouv. 155.
15h. Law that is deficient is better than law that is uncertain. Lofft. 395.
15g. An act of legislature to have force of law must be intelligibly expressed and when too vague is a nullity. Larkin v. Consolidated Telegraph, 85 N.Y.S. (2d) 631.
15f. Too great subtlety is disapproved of in law; for such nice pretense of certainty confounds true and legal certainty. Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 175; 4 Coke, 5.
15e. Where the law is uncertain, there is no law. Black's, 1181; Bouv. 160.
15d. The law requires, not conjecture, but certainty. Coffin v. Ogden, 85 U.S. 120, 124.
15c. Subsequent words added for the purpose of certainty are to be referred to preceding words in which certainty is wanting. Wing. Max. 169; 6 Coke, 236.
15b. Uncertain things are held for nothing. Day. Ir. KB. 33.
15a. That is certain which can be made certain. 2 Bl. Comm. 143; 1 Bouv. Inst. 78; 4 Kent, Comm. 462; Broom, Max. 624. But that is more certain which is certain of itself. 9 Coke, 47a.
15. CERTAIN, CERTAINTY, UNCERTAIN (See also: AMBIGUITY -:- DESCRIBE -:- DOUBT)
14q. That which is null produces no effect. Tray. Leg. Max. 519.
14p. The word `cause' in its ordinary and usual definition may be deemed to mean that which occasions or effects a result. Kemp v. John Chatillon & Sons, 169 F.2d 203, 206.
14o. To cause is to bring about, to bring into existence. C.L.M.
14n. A necessary or inevitable cause — a cause without which the effect in question could not have happened. Hayes v. R.R. Co., 111 U.S. 228.
14m. A vague and uncertain cause is not a reasonable cause. 5 Coke, 57.
14l. He who fails in a syllable fails in his whole cause. Bract. fol. 211.

14k. When that which I do does not have effect as I do it, let it have as much effect as it can; i.e., in some other way. Jackson ex dem. Troup v. Blodget, 16 Johns. (N.Y.) 172, 178; Vandervolgen v. Yates, 3 Barb. Ch. (N.Y.) 242, 261. 4 Kent, Comm. 493.
14j. Things are construed according to that which was the cause thereof. Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3, n. 4.
14i. Remove the cause and the effect will cease. 2 Bl. Comm. 203.
14h. Where the law compels a man to show cause, it is necessary that the cause be just and lawful. 2 Inst. 269.
14g. It shall have effect as far as it can have effect. Cowp. 600; 4 Kent, Comm. 493; Shep. Touch. 87.
14f. The cause of a cause is the cause of the effect. 12 Mod. 639; Bouv. 119; Black's, 177.
14e. He who overthrows the cause overthrows its future effects. 10 Coke, 51.
14d. The effect follows the cause. Wing. Max. 226.
14c. In law, the immediate and not the remote cause is looked at, or considered. 12 East, 648; 3 Kent, Comm. 302; Story, Bailm. s. 515; Bacon, Max. reg. 1.
14b. The cause and origin is the substance of the thing; the cause and origin of a thing are the material from which negotiations are produced. 1 Coke, 99; Wing. Max. 41, max. 21
14a. The cause of the thing causing is the cause of the effect. 4 Camp. 284; Marble v. City of Worcester, 4 Gray (Mass.) 398.
(See Also: RELATION)
14. CAUSE, EFFECT

13s. No rule of law protects a buyer who wilfully closes his ears to information, or refuses to make inquiry when circumstances of grave suspicion imperatively demand it. Lytly v. Lansing, 147 US 59, 72.
13r. The buyer buys for the lowest price he can; the seller sells for the highest price he can. 2 Kent, Comm. 486; Davoue v. Fanning, 2 Johns. Ch. (N.Y.) 252, 256.
13q. In the contract of sale, an ambiguous agreement is to be interpreted against the seller. Dig. 50, 17, 172; Black's, 2d. 64.
13p. Let the seller beware. Lofft. 328; Hargous v. Stone, 5 N.Y. 73, 82.
13o. A thing to be sold must be certain. To make a valid sale, there must be certainty as to the thing which is sold. Bract. fol. 61b.
13n. Those things which, by way of commendation, are stated at sales, if they are openly apparent, do not bind the seller. Dig. 18, 43, m.
13m. Mere recommendation of an article does not bind the vendor of it.] Dig. 4, 3, 37; 2 Kent, Comm. 485; Broom, Max. 781.
13l. Purchaser without notice is not obliged to discover his own hurt. 4 Bouv. Inst. n. 4336.
13k. Law favors public commerce. Wing. Max. p. 738, max. 198.
13j. Nothing can be demanded in payment before that time when, in the nature of things, it can be paid. Dig. 50, 17, 186.
13i. He is fraudulent who sells the same thing twice. Jenk. Cent. 107. Law does not suffer that the same thing be twice paid. Black's, 2d. 679.
13h. The price stands in the place of the thing sold. 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 939; 2 Bulst. 312.
13g. In the price of buying and selling, it is naturally allowed to the contracting parties to overreach each other. 1 Story, Cont. 606.
13f. The payment of the price of a thing is held as a purchase, [operates as a purchase or sale]. Jenk. Cent. p. 56, case 2; 2 Kent, Comm. 387.
13e. The purchaser runs the risk of the loss of a thing sold, though not delivered. 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 939; 2 Kent, Comm. 498, 499.
13d. There should be no commerce in illicit or prohibited goods. 3 Kent, Comm. 262, note.
13c. He who has the right of giving has also the right of selling and granting. Dig. 50, 17, 163.

13b. Caveat emptor (let a buyer beware); the buyer ought not to be ignorant that he is purchasing the rights of another. Hob. 99; Barnard v. Kellogg, 10 Wall. (77 U.S.) 388; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 690; Co. Litt. 102a; 1 Bouv. Inst. 383; 1 Story, Eq. Jur. 6.
13a. To sell is one thing; to consent to sale is another thing. Dig. 50, 17, 160.
13. BUYING & SELLING (See Also: ECONOMICS -:- PROPERTY)
12j. He who does any benefit to another for me is considered as doing it to me. 2 Inst. 501.
12i. What I approve I do not reject. I cannot approve and reject at the same time. I cannot take the benefit of an instrument, and at the same time repudiate it. Broom, Max. 712.
12h. Privilege is, as it were, a private law. 2 Bulst. 189.
12g. He who bears the burden of a thing should also receive the advantage or benefit arising from it. 1 Coke, 99a; Broom, Max. 638; 1 Serg. & R. (Pa) 180.

12f. He who receives the advantage or benefit from a thing should also bear the burden or disadvantages attending it. 1 Coke, 99; Broom, Max. 706-713; 1 Kames, Eq. 289; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1433; 1 Story, Const. 78.
12e. One who avails himself of the benefits conferred by a statute cannot deny its validity. Buck v. Kuykendall, 267 U.S. 307, 316.
12d. It is a rule of the ancient law that all persons have liberty to renounce those privileges which have been conferred for their benefit. Code. 1, 3, 51; Id. 2, 3, 29.
12c. A privilege avails not against the commonwealth. Bacon, Max. 25; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 17; Noy, Max. 34.
12b. A benefit is not conferred on one who is unwilling to receive it; that is to say, no one can be compelled to accept a benefit against his consent. Dig. 50, 17, 69; Broom, Max. 699, note.
12a. A privilege is a personal benefit, and dies with the person. 3 Bulst. 8.
12. BENEFITS, PRIVILEGES (See Also: GRANTS)
11w. In the presence of the superior power, the inferior power ceases. Jenk. Cent. 214, c. 53; 13 How. (54 U.S.) 142. The less authority is merged in the greater. Broom, Max. 111.
11v. Power is not synonymous with right. Poe v. Seaborn, 282 U.S. 101, 113.
11u. Reason and authority, the two brightest lights of the world. 4 Inst. 320.
11t. He who contemns (or contemptuously treats) a command  contemns the party who gives it. 12 Coke, 97.
11s. One lawfully commanding must be obeyed. Jenk. Cent. 120. lit. He who contemns (or contemptuously treats) a command contemns the party who gives it. 12 Coke, 97.
11r. Paternal power should consist [or be exercised] in affection, not in atrocity. Black's, 2d. 882.
11q. Every ratification relates back and is equivalent to a prior authority. Broom, Max. 757, 871; Chit. Cont. 196.
11p. A power is strictly interpreted. Jenk. Cent. p. 17, case 29, in marg.
11o. That power is vain [idle or useless] which never comes into action, [which is never exercised.] 2 Coke, 51.
11n. Power should follow justice, not go before it. 3 Bulst. 199; 2 Inst. 454.
11m. The authority of no man ought to avail with us, that we should not follow better opinions should any one present them. Co. Litt. 383b.
11l. The legality of power must be estimated not by what it will do, but by what it can do. Block v. Hirsh, 256 U.S. 135, 162.
11k. An equal has no power over an equal. Jenk. Cent. 174. (Example: One of two judges of the same court cannot commit the other for contempt.)
11j. One has authority when he has a legal or rightful power to act. C.L.M.
11i. Where there is no authority for establishing a rule, there is no necessity of obeying it. Black's, 2d. 1181; Day. Ir. KB. 69. Useless power is to no purpose. Branch, Princ.
11h. Supreme power can dissolve itself. Bacon, Max.
11g. When anything is commanded, everything by which it can be accomplished is also commanded. 5 Coke, 116.
11f. Power can never be delegated which the authority said to delegate never possessed itself. N.J. Steam Co. v. Merch Bank, 6 How. (47 U.S.) 344, 407.
11e. That power is to no purpose which never comes into act, or which is never exercised. 2 Coke, 51.
11d. In the greatest power there is the least freedom. Hob. 159.
11c. Nothing is so becoming to authority as to live in accordance with the laws. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 17, s. 11.
11b. The derivative power cannot be greater than the original from which it is derived. Noy, Max.; Wing. Max. 66; Finch, Law, b. 1, c. 3.

11a. A delegated power cannot be again delegated. 2 Inst. 597; Black's, 2d. 347; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1300. A deputy cannot have (or appoint) a deputy. Story, Ag. s. 13; 9 Coke, 77; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1936.
(See Also: SERVANT -:- JURISDICTION)
11. AUTHORITY, POWER

10e. An overt act, failure, interception, or prevention in the execution of a crime are factors inherent in the general legal concept of an attempt. People v. Urbana, 163 N.E.2d 511, 514, 18 Ill.2d 81.
10d. An attempt is an intent to do a particular criminal thing with an act toward it falling short of the thing intended. State v. Davis, 229 A.2d 842, 844, 108 N.H. 158.
10c. The attempt becomes of consequence, if the effect follows. Jenk. Cent. 55; Bouv. 145.
10b. An attempt does not harm unless a consequence follow. 11 Coke, 98; Cycl. Dict. 700.
10a. What an attempt is, is not defined in law. 2 Bulst. 277; 6 Coke, 42.
10. ATTEMPT
9f. The people have a right to bear arms for the defense of themselves and the state. An American Maxim.
9e. Arms used in the committing an offense include only that which is recognized as a dangerous weapon. C.L.M.
9d. Laws are silent amidst arms. 4 Inst. 70.
9c. It is a liberty of free citizens to retain arms for their protection and according to their condition. People v. Horton, 264 N.Y.S. 84, 88.
9b. Under the name of arms are included, not only shields and swords and helmets, but also clubs and stones. Co. Litt. 162.
9a. The laws permit the taking up of arms against armed persons. 2 Inst. 574.
9. ARMS
8j. An argument drawn from things commonly happening is frequent in law. Broom, Max. 44.
8i. An argument drawn from authority is the strongest in the law. "The book cases are the best proof of what the law is." Co. Litt. 254a.
8h. No argument can be drawn against the use of a thing from its abuse. Branch, Princ.
8g. An argument drawn from what is inconvenient is good in law, because the law will not permit any inconvenience. Co. Litt. 66a.
8f. An argument deduced from impossibility greatly avails in law. Co. Litt. 92.
8e. From like things to like things we are to proceed by the same rule or reason, [i.e., we are allowed to argue from the analogy of cases.] Branch, Princ.
8d. An argument from a similar case, or from analogy, is good in law. Co. Litt. 191.
8c. He who approbates does not reprobate, [it is an unsound argument to both accept and reject the same thing.] Black's, 2d. 978.
8b. An argument from the greater to the less is of no force negatively; conversely it is. Jenk. Cent. 281.
8a. An argument from division [of the subject] is of the greatest force in law. Co. Litt. 213b; 6 Coke, 60.
8. ARGUMENTS (See Also: PLEA -:- LEGAL ACTION)
7m. Implied repeals are not favored in Law. United States v. Noce, 268 U.S. 613, 619.
7l. An amendment [to the original instrument] is not a repeal. [Fundamental principles are not annulled by amendment.]. Mass. Bond & Ins. Co. v. U.S., 352 U.S. 128, 139.
7k. Whose it is to institute, his it is also to abrogate. Broom, Max. 785.
7j. That which is null produces no effect. Tray. Leg. Max. 519.
7i. All shall have liberty to renounce those things which have been established in their favor. Code. 2, 3, 29; Broom, Max. 625.
7h. To derogate from a law is to take away part of it; to abrogate a law is to abolish it entirely. Dig. 50, 17, 102; 1 Bouv. Inst. n. 91.
7g. By the same mode by which a thing is bound, by that it is also released or dissolved. 2 Rolle, 21, 39; Jenk. Cent. 74; Broom, Max. 884, 891; 6 Coke, 53.
7f. What is done without consideration or reflection, upon better consideration we should revoke or undo. Jenk. Cent. 116.
7e. Laws are abrogated or repealed by the same authority by which they are made. Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 785.

7d. An act already begun, the completion of which depends on the will of the parties, may be revoked; but if it depend on the will of a third person, or on a contingency, it cannot be revoked. Bacon, Max. reg. 20. Story, Ag. s. 424.

7c. It is a perpetual law that no human or positive law can be perpetual; and a clause in a law which precludes the power of abrogation is void ab initio. Broom, Max, 3d Lond. ed. 27; Bacon, Max. reg. 19.
7b. It matters not whether a revocation be by words or by acts. Cro. Car. 49; Branch, Princ.
7a. When the form is not observed, it is inferred that the act is annulled. 12 Coke, 7.
7. ANNUL, ABROGATE, REVOKE (See Also: INVALID)

6k. An ambiguity in a writing which will warrant the introduction of parol evidence is duplicity, indistinctness, or an uncertainty of meaning or expression, and mere omission or mistake is not an ambiguity. Beidler v. Davis, 50 N.E.2d 613, 616, 72 Ohio App. 27.
6j. Indistinctness in a written instrument is ambiguity. Black's, 2d 64.
6i. Ambiguity is doubtfulness; doubleness of meaning. Chapman v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 173 S.E. 801, 803, 172 S.C. 250.
6h. In obscure cases, we look at what is most probable, or what most commonly happens. Dig. 50, 17, 114; Dig. 50, 17, 9; 2 Kent, Comm. 557.
6g. In cases of ambiguity, such an interpretation should always be made that what is inconvenient and absurd may be avoided. 4 Inst. 328.

6f. In an ambiguous expression of law, that signification is to be preferred which is consonant with equity, especially when the spirit of the law can be collected from it. Dig. 1, 3, 19; Broom, Max. 576.
6e. In ambiguous expressions, the intention of the person using them is chiefly to be regarded. Dig. 50, 17, 96; Broom, Max. 567.
6d. It is a wretched state of things when law is vague and mutable. 2 Salk. 512.
6c. A patent ambiguity cannot be cleared up by extrinsic evidence. Lofft, 249.

6b. A latent ambiguity in the language may be removed by evidence; for whatever ambiguity arises from an extrinsic fact may be explained (or removed) by extrinsic evidence. Bacon, Max. Reg. 23; 2 Kent, Comm. 557.
6a. An ambiguous answer is to be taken against him who offers it. 10 Coke, 58, 59.
6. AMBIGUITY (See also: CERTAIN -:- DOUBT)
5n. Those things do not differ which agree in substance, though not in the same words. Jenk. Cent. p. 70, case 32.
5m. A naked agreement [i.e., without consideration] does not beget an obligation. Dig. 2, 14, 7, 4; Broom, Max. 746.
5l. The expressed agreement of the parties overcomes or prevails against the law, because the agreement of the parties makes the law of the contract. Story, Ag. s 368; Dig. 16, 3, 1, 6; 2 Coke, 73.
5k. One of two opposite positions being affirmed, the other is denied. 3 Rolle, 422.
5j. By special agreement, things are allowed which are not otherwise permitted. Co. Litt. 166.
5i. Nothing can be effected by an agreement that there shall be no accountability for fraud. Dig. 2, 14, 27, 3; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 622, 188, n.
5h. There is no doubt that the rights of others cannot be prejudiced by private agreements. Dig. 2, 15, 3, pr.; Broom, Max. 623.
5g. If it does not appear what was agreed upon, the consequence will be that we must follow that which is the usage of the place where the agreement was made. Dig. 50, 17, 34.
5f. The part which does not agree with its whole is entitled to small or no consideration. Plowd. 101; Shep. Touch. 87.

5e. Out of a nude or naked pact [that is, a bare parol agreement without consideration] no action arises. Bract. fol. 99; Fleta, lib. 2, c. 56, s. 3; Plowd. 305. A parol agreement, without a valid consideration, cannot be made the foundation of an action. Code, 2, 3, 10; 2 Bl. Comm. 445; Smith, Cont. 85, 86.
5d. Agreements give the law to the contract. Halk. Max. 118.
5c. Those things which are impossible to be given, or which are not in the nature of things, are regarded as no part of an agreement. Dig. 50, 17, 135.
5b. An agreement induced by fraud cannot stand. Dig. 2, 14, 7, s. 9.
5a. When there is a disagreement in the substance, it appears that there is no acceptance. Gardner v. Lane, 12 Allen (Mass.) 44.
(See also: CONSENT -:- CONTRACTS)
5. AGREE, AGREEMENT
4j. He who commands a thing to be done is held to have done it himself. Story, Bailm. s. 147.
4i. An assigner is clothed with the rights of his principal. Halk. Max. 14; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 415; Wing. Max. 56.

4h. An agent, as such, does not have title to the principal's property, although he may be intrusted with possession, and although he may have power to pass title. Rogers v. U.S. Rubber Co., 20 A.2d 626, 627, 91 N.H. 398.
4g. Whatever things or rights that are acquired by an agent are acquired for his principal. Story, Ag. s. 403.
4f. Faith must be observed. An agent must not violate the confidence reposed in him. Story, Ag. s. 192.

4e. A delegate cannot delegate; an agent cannot delegate his functions to a subagent without the knowledge or consent of the principal; the person to whom an office or duty is delegated cannot lawfully devolve the duty on another, unless he be expressly authorized so to do. 9 Coke, 77; Broom, Max. 840; 2 Kent, Comm. 633; 2 Steph. Comm. 119.
4d. An agent is a person authorized by another to act on his account and under his control. Wasilowski v. Park Bridge Corp., 156 F.2d 612, 614.
4c. What I cannot do by myself, I cannot by another [i.e., an agent.] 4 Coke, 24b; 11 Coke, 87a; Jenk. Cent. 237.

4b. He who does a thing by another is considered as doing it himself [i.e., the acts of an agent are the acts of the principal.] Broom, Max. 817, 818, et seq.; 1 Bl. Comm. 429; Story, Ag. s. 440; Co. Litt. 258; 2 Bouv. Inst. n. 1273; Comm. v. Dewitt, 10 Mass. 155.
4a. The same person cannot be both agent and patient; i.e., the doer and person to whom the thing is done. Jenk. Cent. 40.
4. AGENT
3h. In many counselors there is safety. 4 Inst. 1.
3g. A wise man does every thing advisedly. 4 Inst. 4.
3f. The advice of many persons is requisite in great affairs. 4 Inst. 1.
3e. Every one is free to ascertain for himself whether a recommendation (or advice) is advantageous to his interests. Upton v. Vail, 6 Johns. (N.Y.) 181, 184; 5 Am. Dec. 210.
3d. A simple recommendation does not bind the party offering it. Dig. 4, 3, 37; 2 Kent, Comm. 485; Broom, Max. 3d Lond. ed. 700; Smith v. Goodrich, 5 Johns. (N.Y.) 354.

3c. Opinion is of two kinds, namely, common opinion, which springs up among grave and discreet men, and which has the appearance of truth, and opinion which springs up only among light and foolish men, without the semblance of truth. 4 Coke, 107.
3b. No man is bound for the advice he gives. Story, Bailm. s. 155.
3a. Hasty counsels are rarely prosperous. 4 Inst. 57.
3. ADVICE, OPINION
2aa. No one can contradict his own deed. 2 Inst. 66.
2z. There is no surer way to find out what parties meant, than to see what they have done. Brooklyn Ins. Co. v. Dutcher, 5 Otto (95 U.S.) 269, 273.
2y. No one can do that indirectly which cannot be done directly. C.L.M.
2x. A thing done cannot be undone. 1 Kames, Eq. 96, 259.
2w. When there is doubt about an act, it receives interpretation from the (known) feelings of the actor. Dig. 50, 17, 68, 1.
2v. A party's own act should prejudice himself, not his adversary. Dig. 50, 17, 155.
2u. All actions in the world are limited within certain periods. Bract. 52.
2t. External acts indicate undisclosed thoughts. 8 Coke, 146b.
2s. To write is to act. 2 Rolle, 89; 4 Bl. Comm. 80; Broom, Max. 312, 967.
2r. Acts indicate the intention. 8 Coke, 291; Broom, Max. 270; Troy v. Yelle, 176 P.2d 459, 463.
2q. An act done by me, against my will, is not my act. Branch, Princ.; Bract. 101b; Cycl. Dict. 25.
2p. Every man is presumed to intend the natural and probable consequences of his own voluntary act. Greenl. Ev. s. 18; 9 East, 277.
2o. Take away the will, and every action will be indifferent. Bract. 2.
2n. One may not do an act to himself. Bouv. 146.
2m. When many join in one act, the law will construe it as the act of him who could best accomplish it. Noy, Max. 38.
2l. A repugnant act cannot be brought into being, i.e., cannot be made effectual. Plowd. 355.
2k. No man ought to be burdened in consequence of another's act. 2 Kent, Comm. 646.
2j. Your motive gives a name to your act. Bract. 2b, 101b.
2i. Where there is no act, there can be no force. 4 Coke, 43.
2h. By various acts experience frames the law. 4 Inst. 50.
2g. Environment illuminates the meaning of acts, as context does that of words. Cramer v. United States, 325 U.S. 1, 33.
2f. Things which are done simultaneously with an act are supposed to be inherent in it; to be a constituent part of it. Co. Litt. 236b.
2e. Certain legal consequences are attached to the voluntary act of a person. Duncan v. Landis, 106 Fed. 839.
2d. Not what is said, but what is done, is to be regarded. Co. Litt. 36; 6 Bingh. 310; Osborn v. Cook, 11 Cush. (Mass.) 536.
2c. Every action proceeds in its own way or course. Jenk. Cent. 77.
2b. Acts required to be done by law do not admit of qualification. Hob. 153; Branch, Princ.
2a. The frequency of an act effects much. 4 Coke, 78; Wing. Max. 192.
2. ACT, ACTS, ACTIONS
1e. Laws cannot prevent accidents nor can a law equally protect all against them. Louisiana v. Resweber, 329 U.S. 459, 465.
1d. Mistakes, neglect, or misconducts are not to be regarded as accidents. Citizens Nat. Bank v. Cincinnati, 19 Ohio Dec. 685, 687.
1c. No one is held to answer for the effects of a superior force, or of an accident, unless his own fault has contributed. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 72, s. 16.
1b. A fortuitous event is not to be expected or presumed, and no one is bound to foresee it. 4 Coke, 66; Hardr. 82, arg.
1a. An unforeseen event, occurring without the will or design of the person whose mere act causes it, is known as an accident. Burkhard v. Travelers' Ins. Co., 102 Pa. 262.
